**The Notes:**

- Maturity: The Notes will mature on November 15, 2028.

- Interest Payments: Each series of Notes will pay interest semi-annually in cash in arrears on April 1 and October 1 of each year, beginning
on October 1, 2023.

- Guarantees: Prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will not be guaranteed. From and after satisfaction of the Escrow
Release Conditions and immediately following the consummation of the Acquisition (or on the Issue Date if the Acquisition closes
concurrently with this offering), subject to certain exceptions, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by Parent and each of
Parent’s existing and future wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries that are guarantors under the Term Loan Credit Agreement (as
defined herein) (the “Subsidiary Guarantors” and, together with Parent, the “Guarantors”). To the extent lenders under the Term Loan Credit
Agreement release any Guarantor from its obligations, subject to certain exceptions, such Guarantor will also be released from its
obligations under the Notes. See “Description of Notes—Brief Description of the Notes—Note Guarantees.”

- Security and Ranking: If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will initially be obligations solely of
the Escrow Issuer, secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and all deposits and investments therein.
From and after satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions and immediately following the consummation of the Acquisition (or on the
Issue Date if the Acquisition closes concurrently with this offering), the Notes and the related guarantees will be general, senior secured
obligations of the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors, secured on a first-priority basis by security interests in the Fixed Asset Collateral (as
defined herein) and on a second-priority basis in the Current Asset Collateral (as defined herein), in each case, subject to certain limitations
and permitted liens. The Notes and the related guarantees will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Ultimate Issuer’s and the
Guarantors’ subordinated indebtedness and be effectively senior to all of the Ultimate Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ unsecured indebtedness,
including the Existing Unsecured Notes (as defined herein), and indebtedness secured by liens junior to the liens securing the Notes,
including, in the case of the Fixed Asset Collateral, the ABL Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein), in each case, to the extent of the
value of the assets securing the Notes. The Notes and the related guarantees will rank equally in right of payment with all of the Ultimate
Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ senior indebtedness, without giving effect to collateral arrangements, and equal to all of the Ultimate Issuer’s
and the Guarantors’ senior indebtedness secured on the same priority basis as the Notes, including the Existing Secured Notes (as defined
herein) and the Term Loan Credit Agreement. The Notes and the related guarantees will be effectively subordinated to any of the Ultimate
Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ indebtedness that is secured by assets that do not constitute collateral for the Notes to the extent of the value of
such assets, and indebtedness that is secured by a senior-priority lien, including our ABL Revolving Credit Facility to the extent of the value
of the Current Asset Collateral, and will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of Parent’s subsidiaries that are not Subsidiary
Guarantors.

- Optional Redemption: Each series of Notes may be redeemed on or after June 1, 2025 at the redemption prices set forth in this offering
memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. At any time prior to June 1, 2025, each series
of Notes may be redeemed at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes to be redeemed, plus accrued and
unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, plus a “make-whole” premium. At any time prior to June 1, 2025, the Issuer
may also redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of Notes with an amount equal to the proceeds of certain equity
offerings at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the
redemption date. At any time prior to June 1, 2025, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of
Notes during each calendar year at a purchase price equal to 103% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes to be redeemed, plus
accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date.

- Change of Control: If we undergo a change of control, subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer is required to offer to purchase each series of
Notes from holders at a purchase price equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount of such series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid
interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. In connection with any offer to purchase any series of Notes, if holders of no less
than 90% of the aggregate principal amount of such series of Notes validly tender their Notes, the Issuer is entitled to redeem any remaining
Notes of such series at the price offered to each holder.

**USE OF NON-GAAP FINANCIAL MEASURES**

To supplement our financial information presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we use the following
non-GAAP financial measures to clarify and enhance an understanding of past performance: EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma
Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the
Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the
Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing
cash flows. We believe that the presentation of these financial measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our
financial performance. We further believe that these financial measures are useful financial metrics to assess our
operating performance from period-to-period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our
core business. We use certain of these financial measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our
performance relative to that of our competitors. We utilize Segment profit as the primary measure of our segment
specific performance. The following terms have the following meanings:

    - “Adjusted EBITDA” means EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to (i) for Solenis, the impact of
non-recurring charges, non-cash purchase accounting adjustments related to the Legacy Acquisitions
and the Sigura Contribution, non-service costs for pensions and other non-operational items, one-time
consulting and transaction costs related to the Acquisition, management fees paid to Sponsor, realized
and unrealized foreign exchange gains/losses, as well as other non-recurring and unusual costs and, (ii)
for Diversey, the impact of non-recurring charges, non-cash purchase accounting adjustments, nonservice costs for pensions and other non-operational items, one-time consulting and transaction costs
related to the Acquisition, realized and unrealized foreign exchange gains/losses, tax adjustments not
related to income tax, factoring and securitization fees, COVID-19 inventory charges, as well as other
non-recurring and unusual costs.

    - “Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega)” means
Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to, with respect to Solenis the impact of incentive
compensation at 1.0x of the applicable targets, the pre-close EBITDA of Clearon and the unaudited pro
forma impact for certain estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions (i) that were taken
within 18 months of the closing of the Solenis Acquisition and (ii) that were taken or are expected to
be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Clearon Acquisition and, with respect to Diversey,
expected savings from Project Mega.

    - “Adjusted net operating cash flows” and “Adjusted net investing cash flows” means, for Solenis,
reported net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and net cash provided by (used in)
investing activities, each adjusted for the effects of cash subsequently received as part of our Accounts
Receivable Facility (as defined herein).

    - “EBITDA” means net income (loss) before interest expense, income taxes, depreciation and
amortization (including amortization of pre-publication investment cash costs).

    - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA” means Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to
the Transactions.

    - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and
_Project Mega)” means Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and_
Project Mega) further adjusted to give effect to the Transactions.

    - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies)” means Pro
Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the unaudited pro forma
combined impact for certain estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions expected to be taken
within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the
Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits
from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted

    - “Pro Forma Combined EBITDA” means EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the Transactions.

    - “Segment profit” means, for Solenis, EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-operating income or expense, (ii)
the impact of certain non-cash, non-recurring or other items that are included in net (loss) and

With respect to Adjusted net operating cash flows and Adjusted net investing cash flows, Accounting
Standards Update (“ASU”) 2016-15 requires us to evaluate the transfer of title of receivables sold under our
Accounts Receivable Facility against cash received on previously-sold receivables in exchange for the transfer of
title. Since there is a dichotomy between when we legally transfer title of receivables to ING Luxembourg S.A. or,
in prior periods, MUFG Bank, Ltd. under the receivables purchasing agreements and when the cash is received on
previously-sold receivables, receivables are deemed transferred in exchange for a beneficial interest in the collection
of that receivable. This is considered a non-cash investing activity. Furthermore, ultimate receipts of cash, when
settled with ING Luxembourg S.A. or, in prior periods, MUFG Bank, Ltd., are considered cash flows from investing
activities, as the receipt is considered a return of capital on the beneficial interest.

We believe that this may cause net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and net cash provided by
(used in) investing activities to be potentially misleading to investors. While we do not retain legal ownership of the
receivables sold, the nature, timing, and extent of cash flows have not materially changed as a result of the
agreement. We use these non-GAAP metrics to assess our own liquidity. We believe these non-GAAP metrics
supplement the user’s evaluation of our cash flows and liquidity.

Acquisition and Related Synergies) are intended to provide additional information on a more comparable basis than
would be if provided without such adjustments because they account for initiatives related to back office, sales and
support staff optimization, warehouse and temporary labor efficiency and technology, among others.

Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, or
Adjusted net investing cash flows differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative
measures.

We compensate for these limitations by using EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the
Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and
Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment
profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows along with other comparative tools,
together with U.S. GAAP measurements, to assist in the evaluation of operating performance and liquidity. Such
U.S. GAAP measurements include income before income taxes, and net (loss) amongst other performance metrics.
In evaluating these financial measures, one should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses similar to
those eliminated in this presentation. Our presentation of such measures should not be construed as an inference that
our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items.

We may incur expenses similar to the adjustments noted herein to calculate Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro
Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions,
Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related
Synergies). However, the magnitude of such adjustments for the periods noted below is not necessarily indicative of
the magnitude of such adjustments in future periods.

See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data” for a reconciliation of these
measures to our directly comparable GAAP measures.

Because the leverage ratios presented in this offering memorandum are based, in part, on Adjusted
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma
Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the
Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the
Acquisition and Related Synergies), these measures are similarly impacted by the limitations referenced above and
also should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for GAAP measures.

**BASIS OF PRESENTATION**

The consolidated financial statements of Parent (“Successor”) and Solenis (“Predecessor”) as of and for
each of the years ended September 30, 2022, September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020 and as of and for the
three and six months ended March 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2022, and the periods November
9, 2021 to March 31, 2022, and October 1, 2021 to November 8, 2021 have been prepared in accordance U.S.
GAAP, and include the financial statements of Parent and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.

The consolidated and combined financial statements of Diversey Holdings, Ltd. as of and for the years
ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021 and as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and
March 31, 2022 have also been prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP, and include the financial statements of
Diversey Holdings, Ltd and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.

Parent was formed on June 29, 2021 and exists as the “Successor” entity for the specific purpose of having
consummated the Solenis Acquisition. Parent also exists as the Successor entity for the specific purpose of having
received the contribution of the Sigura business, which was acquired by Platinum on February 28, 2019 and was
contributed to Parent (the “Sigura Contribution”) immediately following the Solenis Acquisition on November 9,
2021.

Parent was formed under a group of holding companies. These holding companies and partnerships are
collectively referred to as the “Holding Companies.” The Holding Companies have no business operations or assets
other than cash, cash equivalents, certain related party loans between and among the Holding Companies and
Solenis, and investments in the ownership interests described above.

Upon the consummation of the Solenis Acquisition, Platinum acquired all of the capital stock and equity
interests of the entities comprising the legacy Solenis operations from Solenis UK Holdings Limited.

Immediately following the Solenis Acquisition, the Sigura Contribution was effected, which included all of
Sigura’s direct and indirect subsidiaries, and which contributed the Sigura business to the Issuer from affiliates of
Platinum. Accordingly, the conclusion of the Solenis Acquisition and Sigura Contribution resulted in the
consolidation of the operations of the legacy Solenis and Sigura businesses (under the Solenis umbrella) from
November 9, 2021 within the financial statements contained in this offering memorandum as presented under the
“Successor” periods.

Prior to the formation of Parent and the occurrence of the Solenis Acquisition, the Solenis business existed
under the “Predecessor” entity known as Solenis UK International.

Solenis UK International itself was not acquired as part of the Solenis Acquisition. Instead, the Solenis
Acquisition was structured to acquire all of the entities that were direct or indirect subsidiaries of Solenis UK
International.

The consolidated statement of operations of Parent for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2022,
September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, and the consolidated balance sheet data as of September 30, 2022 and
September 30, 2021 have been derived from the audited consolidated financial statements and related notes of
Parent for the year ended September 30, 2022, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Due to the impact
of the Solenis Acquisition by Parent on November 9, 2021, the audited consolidated financial information of Parent
for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2022 is presented in two distinct periods to indicate the application of a
different basis of accounting between the periods presented: (1) for periods prior to the Solenis Acquisition (October
1, 2021 through November 8, 2021, labeled Predecessor) and (2) for periods after the Solenis Acquisition
(November 9, 2021 through September 30, 2022, labeled Successor).

This offering memorandum also includes the unaudited interim consolidated financial information of
Parent for the six months ended March 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2022, and the periods
November 9, 2021 to March 31, 2022, and October 1, 2021 to November 8, 2021, which has been derived from the
unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of Parent. Due to the impact of the Solenis Acquisition by
Parent on November 9, 2021, the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial information of Parent for the
six months ended March 31, 2022 is presented in two distinct periods to indicate the application of a different basis

**Company Overview**

**_History and Evolution_**

The Escrow Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Issuer. The Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of
Parent. Parent, doing business as “Solenis” from November 9, 2021, was formed on June 29, 2021 in connection
with the Solenis Acquisition as an exempted limited partnership registered and domiciled under the laws of the
Cayman Islands. Parent and several other holding companies and partnerships were formed by affiliates of Platinum.
Parent exists as the “successor” entity for the specific purposes of (1) having consummated the Solenis Acquisition,
and (2) having received the Sigura Contribution. Accordingly, the consummation of the Solenis Acquisition and the
Sigura Contribution resulted in the consolidation of the operations of the legacy Solenis and Sigura businesses into
the business of Parent from November 9, 2021. On September 9, 2022, Clearon was acquired by Parent and its
subsidiaries from Hui Yu Xin American LLC.

**_Solenis Business_**

Headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, Solenis is a leading supplier of specialty chemicals and services
to the pulp and paper, mining, food and beverage, power generation, petroleum refining, chemical processing,
general manufacturing, municipal and pool markets. Solenis’ product and service line is comprised of chemical and
equipment technologies and services designed to help customers improve operational efficiencies, enhance product
quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact. Solenis sells products and provide services
throughout the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific primarily to customers operating within the pulp and paper, the
water treatment and the pool industries.

Solenis has 49 manufacturing facilities strategically located near customers in approximately 22 countries
around the globe to ensure seamless supply continuity, and employs a team of more than 6,600 professionals
(including more than 2,400 field representatives with deep industry knowledge) in 130 countries across six
continents. Solenis has 11 labs consisting of R&D centers and Customer Applications Laboratories spanning every
region it serves, aimed at making water work more effectively and more sustainably for its more than 24,500
customers. Key brands delivered by Solenis include Zetag™, Kymene™, Hercobond™, Spectrum™, Praestol™,
PerForm™ and Percol™, HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, and HTH Spa®.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Solenis generated Net sales and Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $4.4 billion and $742 million, respectively,
reflecting an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 17%. See “—Summary Historical Financial and Combined Financial
Data.”

**_Diversey Business_**

Headquartered in Fort Mill, South Carolina, Diversey is a leading global supplier and manufacturer of
sustainable, high-performance hygiene, retail and grocery, infection prevention and cleaning solutions to the facility
management, retail, healthcare, hospitality, food and beverage, commercial laundry, food service, education and
government, dairy, agriculture and buildings service contractors (“BSC”) markets. Diversey’s product and service

1


-----

line is comprised of a wide range of hygiene, infection prevention and cleaning solutions that drive operational
improvements, enhance customers’ food safety initiatives and protect the environment. Diversey sells products and
provides services throughout the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific primarily to customers operating within the
institutional and food and beverage industries. Key brands delivered by Diversey include Lysol®, CLAX®, Suma®
and TASKI.

Diversey maintains 21 manufacturing facilities (including the “Project Mega” plant facility (the new
manufacturing and warehouse facility site located in northern Kentucky)) in 17 countries around the globe to allow
Diversey to provide efficient and effective service to its customers across 80 countries. Diversey employs a team of
more than 9,000 professionals (including approximately 1,400 technicians to provide on-site services to customers).
Diversey has 7 labs spanning every region it serves with over 1,100 patents, over 2,000 unique chemical
formulations and an extensive and differentiated suite of dosing and dispensing equipment and floor care machines
supporting its intellectual property offering for more than 85,000 customers.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively,
reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020,
Diversey generated Net sales of $2.8 billion, $2.6 billion and $2.6 billion, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of
$330 million, $410 million and $401 million, respectively. See “—Summary Historical Financial and Combined
Financial Data.” In addition, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020,
Diversey spent $56 million, $60 million, $55 million and $41 million, respectively, on capital expenditure. For the
twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey spent $78 million, $77
million, $65 million and $46 million, respectively, on dosing and dispensing expenditures.

**_Combined Company_**

We believe that the combination of Solenis and Diversey will create a platform with a shared commercial
focus and significant global scale in complementary end markets. After giving effect to the Transactions, the
combined company will be able to grow and provide a number of attractive cross-selling opportunities, including
meeting customers’ increasing demand for “one-stop shop” service models across water management, cleaning and
hygiene solutions.

After giving effect to the Transactions, we expect to be better positioned to benefit from growing
Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) and macroeconomic trends, including those around customer
sustainability goals and focus points, such as: heightened focus on water consumption and recycling; the need for
improved energy efficiency and raw material management; increased consumer focus on hygiene; increased
environmental legislation being implemented globally; and increased levels of shipping and packaging. Together,
we will offer a diverse, comprehensive portfolio of solutions and services, which will limit any obsolescence risk as
no product or solution represents a material part of our business.

the customer” and create opportunities for new business wins, increasing our customer spending. For example in
hotels today, Solenis has a limited presence in pool solutions while Diversey provides kitchen care, building care,
floor care, infection prevention and laundry care. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe the fact that
Solenis and Diversey provide different services to their combined customers will provide the combined company
with the opportunity to offer existing hotel customers our full suite of products and services, including water
treatment. Similarly, Solenis does not currently serve cruise ships or hospitals but will have the opportunity to offer

After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe that we will be able to implement near-term strategic
initiatives in the legacy Diversey to better optimize processes, drive growth and create value. Some key initiatives
will include (i) increasing scale by bundling our leading global cleaning and water treatment solutions across
Industrial and Food & Beverage to increase win rates and cross-selling opportunities, (ii) increasing efficiencies by
standardizing corporate functions, (iii) implementing a global enterprise resource planning (ERP) system, (iv)
investing in growth opportunities such as expansion efforts within: North America commercial and institutional,
high growth global strategic accounts (“GSAs”), distributor partnerships and building out new product introduction
(NPI) capabilities and (v) applying our performance management capabilities to existing processes. We believe by
creating real-time visibility into financial performance we will be able to drive accountability at a more localized
level and assist in informing business decisions (such as pricing and have better insight into profitability and
distributors’ sell-through). We believe we will be able to further supplement our efforts by deploying commercial
excellence tools such as roll-outs and trainings. Additionally, we believe we can continue implementing Diversey’s
“Project Mega” by continuing to develop Diversey’s manufacturing and warehouse facility in Northern Kentucky
alongside consolidating certain existing service centers to provide manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and
insourcing opportunities.

We believe our business exhibits highly attractive financial characteristics, including significant recurring
revenues, improving margin profile and substantial free cash flow conversion. The combined company will provide
greater scale, a broader global reach, superior customer service capabilities and a number of attractive cross-selling
opportunities. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, we generated pro forma Net sales on a combined
historical basis and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) of $7.2
billion and $1.3 billion, respectively, inclusive of $205 million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from
actions expected to be taken within 24 months after the Acquisition and $40 million of cumulative run-rate annual
cost synergies from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date and $13
million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions already taken or expected to be taken within 24
months of the Clearon Acquisition Closing Date. We believe our combined earnings profile after giving effect to the
Transactions will generate significant free cash flow, which we expect will be used to support growth initiatives and
drive de-leveraging.

We believe that the Transactions create an opportunity to realize meaningful synergies resulting from the
integration of Solenis and Diversey. In combining these two complementary businesses, we believe the combined

reducing environmental impacts. We expect to realize approximately $205 million of synergies from integration

and the consolidation of facilities between the two businesses, as a result of actions expected to be taken within 24
months of the closing of the Transactions. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve such

**_Pool Solutions Segment (12% of Combined Company Net Sales)_**

Our Pool Solutions segment offers water care solutions and value-added services for residential and
commercial pools and spas. The water treatment process begins with testing; specifically pool pH and chlorine
levels on a weekly basis. The next step is balancing, i.e., maintaining certain levels of pH, total alkalinity and
calcium hardness. Sanitizing, which is keeping water clean and disinfected, is most frequently done using stabilized
chlorine products. Specialty maintenance products such as algaecides and clarifiers are typically used on a semimonthly basis, in addition to the normal sanitizing process, to target specific pool needs such as algae prevention or
stain control. Lastly, shock treatment can be used to address one-off pool care needs, especially following inclement
weather and high pool usage.

We are a leading producer of pool chemicals for the residential and commercial markets worldwide and
provide various water treatment products including shock, sanitizer, specialty maintenance products, and test strips.
Our offerings include a full suite of products and applications aimed at public pools, health clubs, aquatic parks,
hotels, motels, apartments and condominiums in the form of water-soluble pods, convenient floaters and automatic
feeders. Our portfolio of brands includes iconic brands such HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time® and HTH

9


-----

Spa®. We believe we are the world’s largest producer of calcium-hypoclorite (“cal-hypo”), a primary chemical used
in water treatment and sanitation.

We believe we are one of only two players with a complete brand and product offering in the U.S. pool and
spa chemicals market and we believe we are the only player with a truly global offering. We have total market
access to all residential channels from Mass Retail (40.6% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended
March 31, 2023), to Professional Dealer (29.3% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31,
2023), to Commercial (10.1% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), to Repack
and Private Label (18.7% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023) and Other Pool
(1.3% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), as well as growing e-commerce
and Direct to Consumer (“DTC”) channels. Demand for products from the Pool Solutions segment is driven by the
existing installed base of pools in the regions it operates, which have seen growth tailwinds due to COVID-driven
investment in outdoor spaces. Going forward, ongoing maintenance of these pools will drive sustainable and
recurring future demand for our products. The Pool Solutions segment generated 12% of pro forma Net sales for the
combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023.

**_Customers and Suppliers & Procurement_**

_Customers_

We serve a large base of customers across a diverse set of end markets. Our customer base for the
combined company includes many of the top paper and industrial players across our Industrial Solutions and
Consumer Solutions segments, including WestRock, International Paper, and Marathon Petroleum, across big-box
retailers such as Wal-Mart and Leslie’s Poolmart in our Pool Solutions segment, across Compass, ISS and
McDonald’s in our Institutional Solutions segment and across PepsiCo and Nestle in our Food & Beverage segment.
We believe that the combination of Solenis and Diversey will further reduce customer concentration. For the twelve
months ended March 31, 2023, the top ten customers for the combined company represent approximately 12% of
total pro forma combined company Net sales with the largest customer representing approximately 2% of pro forma
combined company Net sales. As of March 31, 2023, at Solenis, the top ten customers represented approximately
19% of total Net sales with the top three customers representing approximately 11%. Historically, large accounts
have grown 1.3x faster than the base business, driven by collaboration with customers on new technology
development, embedded service engineers and focus on consistent delivery and service. As of March 31, 2023 at
Diversey, customer concentration was relatively in line with that of Solenis so low customer concentration is set to
become even less concentrated as a result of the combination of Solenis and Diversey. Further, Diversey is a major
global player with capabilities to serve GSAs, which represents approximately 20% of revenue. Both Solenis and
Diversey have long-tenured, diverse and high quality customer relationships.

We believe our customer base is inherently sticky, attributable to the mission critical nature and service-led
models that Solenis and Diversey provide, leading to highly recurring, non-discretionary spend on products and
services. On-site technicians, employees and equipment at customer locations create high switching costs and
disruption risk. As a result, we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our
differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined
company.

_Suppliers & Procurement_

We source materials from multiple suppliers creating low supply chain concentration. On April 30, 2021,
Solenis and BASF agreed to extend the supply agreements applicable to certain products that are critical to Solenis’
supply chain and for which Solenis takes all of BASF’s production, which now will not expire until November
2028. Our largest raw material spend includes General Liquids (5.4% of total spend), Caustic and Chlorine (3.3% of
total spend), Acrylonitrile (2.9% of total spend), HDPE (2.2% of total spend) and Sodium Hydroxide (2.1% of total
spend) resulting in a top five materials of 15.9% or $590 million. The top five key suppliers represent 23% of total
expenditure, or $854 million, with the top supplier representing 13% of total expenditure.

**Industry Overview**

**_Specialty Chemicals – Consumer_**

The Consumer market is comprised of water treatment chemicals and solutions for pulp and paper specific
process applications (e.g., strength additives and sizing agents across wet-end/dry-end of paper process). Based on a
report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, the global Consumer market was estimated to be
approximately $8 billion in 2020.

The Packaging market is one of the key market segments within the Consumer market that can be broken
into consumer packaging and food packaging. Based on the same report, the Consumer packaging market was
estimated to be $2.7 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 3.4% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030,
which we believe will be driven primarily from the growth of e-commerce and megatrends in pharmaceuticals and
cosmetics and beauty. Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023
was generated from the consumer packaging market. Based on the same report, the food packaging market was
estimated to be $1.8 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030
(including food packaging barrier film expected to grow at a 4.7% CAGR), driven by increased demand for
ecofriendly packaging and changing lifestyles centering on more take-away and individually packed food. We
believe the shift away from plastic and the growth in the barrier coating market, which is not included in the market
size estimate, may drive additional growth in food packaging over this period. Approximately 7% of our pro forma
Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the food packaging and molded fiber
packaging market.

The Graphic & Specialty Paper market has been adversely impacted by the continued substitution of
printed material with electronic media. Reduced use of commercial office spaces in Europe and North America as a
result of COVID-19 is also a negative factor for the sector outlook. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market, based on
the same report, was estimated to be $1.9 billion in 2020 and is expected to decline at a 0.9% CAGR for the ten-year
period from 2020 to 2030. However, we have limited exposure to newsprint, which accounts for approximately
2.5% of Consumer Solutions sales, and we are shifting our focus to higher margin products to offset the expected
volume decline in this market. Approximately 5% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31,
2023 was generated from the Graphic & Specialty Paper market.

The Tissue & Towel market is benefiting from strong demographic/socioeconomic trends and increasing
hygiene standards, especially in developing markets. However, stagnating population growth in some mature
markets, and cost-cutting in the public sector and private company spending is expected to limit global market
growth. The Tissue & Towel market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.2 billion in 2020 and is
expected to grow at a 2.6% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030. Approximately 6% of our pro forma Net
sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Tissue & Towel market.

16


-----

**_Specialty Chemicals — Industrial_**

The industrial market supplies water treatment chemicals and solutions for heavy and light industries and
municipalities (e.g., cooling tower, boiler, influent/effluent, process water). Broadly speaking, the industrial market
consists of core water treatment which includes end markets such as pulp, mining and oil and gas, and wastewater,
which includes end markets such as municipal and industrial wastewater markets.

Based on the same report, the global industrial market was estimated to be approximately $23 billion in
2020 and is expected to grow at a 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025 for both the wastewater and
core water treatment markets. The municipal market is expected to grow at a 4.3% CAGR for the five-year period
from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report, as demand continues to increase from higher per capita usage of water,
population growth and increasing regulatory demands. Growth in the core water treatment market, including both
heavy and light industrial markets, is expected to be driven by increasing sustainability and environmental policies,
growing regulatory demands and global industrial growth. This growth is expected to be highest in the food and
beverage market (5.5% CAGR for the five year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report) and the
refining and petrochemicals market (4.0% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same
report). Approximately 20% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated
from the Industrial market.

**_Pool_**

The aftermarket for the residential pool industry is comprised of three main segments: (1) Chemicals, (2)
Equipment, Parts, and Accessories and (3) Services. Our main focus is on the Chemicals segment which is the
largest and most stable component of aftermarket pool spend.

Pool chemicals sales are tied to: (1) the pool installed base and (2) total gallons of treatable water, and not
new builds. The U.S. pool installed base has displayed long-term stability as it has consistently grown for decades,
including all years through the housing-led recession and during the COVID-19 pandemic period, which is
providing current tailwinds for the business. As of December 31, 2022, the installed base of U.S. in ground pools
was 9 million, based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. However, new builds
account for less than 4% of the installed base annually, meaning that new build rates are unlikely to materially
impact our long-term performance.

The Pool Solutions segment also benefits from a stable aftermarket spend that mirrors the steady dynamic
of the installed base. Our chemical-based products result in 100% aftermarket exposure, which reduces our exposure
to cyclical industry trends such as housing starts. Pool chemical use is entirely non-discretionary in that it is a
requirement for owning and using a pool. Pool owners who have already made the significant upfront investment of
constructing a pool, estimated to cost $40,000 to $100,000, will continue to purchase pool chemicals, at the de
minimis annual expense of $300 to $400 in order to maintain their pools.

The pool chemical treatment market includes products such as primary sanitizers (71% of total market
sales), specialty chemicals, other shocks and alternative sanitizers. Primary sanitizers include cal-hypo, sodium
hypochlorite (“sodium-hypo”), trichlor, dichlor and packaged shocks. The total market for U.S. residential pool
chemicals, based on retail dollar value, was approximately $2.6 billion in 2020 and grew by 28% in 2021 to
approximately $3.4 billion, primarily due to higher prices resulting from scarcity of chlorine based on a recent study
by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. We believe the U.S. residential pool chemical market, on a
volume basis, will exceed the expected growth of the installed base of U.S. residential pools, which was estimated to
be 3.0% from 2020 to 2025 based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. We
further believe that volumes in our pool solutions segment will exceed the market as we expand our customer base
and increase market sale with new dealer relationships and e-commerce.

**_Institutional_**

The Institutional Solutions market growth is driven by an aging population, increasing demand for
healthcare facilities, return to office policies continued to drive an increase demand for cleaning, the introduction of
new sanitization standards arising post-COVID and a focus on new infrastructure bills to expand healthcare and
transportation networks. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, the Institutional Solutions

**_Competitive Landscape_**

_Consumer Solutions_

We believe, based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, that we are the
market leader in specialty chemicals for the Consumer Solutions segment. Based on the same report, we believe that
we maintain market leadership positions in almost all technologies and regions. The competitive landscape, as
segmented by geography or technology, remains fragmented. We have particularly strong market positions in
process chemicals within the biocide, contaminant control, defoamer, tissue specialties and pulp specialties
technologies.

Our strength is based on the complete product portfolio, premium product performance and strong technical
support we offer. We believe we have the best and the broadest offering to help customers achieve their operational
efficiencies. We are a trusted supplier known for our data analytics capacities, with a focus on service excellence,
sustainability, productivity and cost savings for our customers.

Many customers are starting to embrace digital technology / data analytics to help track performance and
starting to partner with suppliers with strong R&D capabilities to develop innovative solutions to drive efficiency
and achieve sustainability objectives. This trend is expected to continue and we expect to benefit from it due to our
robust value-added chemistry and technology solutions offering.

_Industrial Solutions_

The global industrial water chemicals market is fragmented, with the top seven players, based on a report
by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021. This is due to the required application-specific expertise and
track-record of performance. Hence, by region and by end-user market, three to five players may have a
disproportionately high share. We believe we have an outsized share of the global pulp and paper market, which is
one of our larger markets within the Industrial Solutions segment.

We believe we offer the lowest per unit cost for comparable chemicals compared to our industry peers and
believe that the competitive pricing is our greatest strength in the Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we
offer an array of innovative solutions and comprehensive product lines both in core water treatment and wastewater
segment. Notable competitors include Ecolab / Nalco, Suez, ChemTreat, Kurita, Kemira and SNF. Ecolab, which
acquired Nalco in 2011, is the largest water treatment player followed by Suez.

Similar to the Consumer market, technology and R&D are becoming increasingly important beyond the
chemical product itself as customers are moving towards advanced analytics to optimize the volume of chemical
treatment, driving select industry participants to increasingly focus on equipment / engineering solutions as opposed
to chemical solutions.

20


-----

_Pool Solutions_

We believe we are the only true global player in the Pool Solutions segment with leading market positions
in North America, South America, and EMEA. We believe the acquisition of Clearon further enhanced our market
leading position. Our primary competitor in this segment is KIK Custom Products, which provides various pool
chemical solutions, with a focus on North America. Other smaller competitors also compete in this market, with
varying breadth and geographical focus, including Hasa Pool, Jandy, Lo-chlor and Jack’s Magic.

We believe we are the world’s largest producer of cal-hypo, a primary chemical used in water treatment
and sanitation. All three of our cal-hypo facilities are co-located with chlor-alkali producers meaning that raw
materials (chlorine and caustic soda) are delivered into our production plants via a direct pipeline. We believe this is
a major competitive advantage and barrier to entry in the Pool Solutions segment as we believe it would not be
economical for our competitors to open a new cal-hypo facility that is not co-located with a supply of raw materials.

The acquisition of Clearon provided additional manufacturing capabilities for trichlor and dichlor and we
are now the only producer of cal-hypo, trichlor and dichlor, which we believe will give us a significant advantage
over our competitors. Further, Clearon’s manufacturing facility located in West Virginia was isolated from the
impact of natural disasters that other competitors have experienced with facilities located on the Gulf Coast.

_Institutional Solutions_

Diversey is a major global player in the Institutional Solutions segment and competes primarily with
Ecolab. Other competitors in this segment include: SC Johnson, Gojo, Kalykim and Jasol. In this highly fragmented
market, Diversey and Ecolab together hold approximately a 20% global market share. Geographically, Diversey
believes it is the number one or number two player in the North America, Europe, Middle East and Africa, Latin
America and Asia-Pacific regions. Other competitors are focused on niche segments and geographies, focusing on
regional and local customers.

Diversey is positioned to compete using a recurring revenue business model built on consumable products
that require periodic replacement and high customer switching costs via a suite of proprietary dosing and dispensing
equipment installed at customer sites. Further, to better compete with Ecolab in North America, Diversey is in the
process of opening a new co-manufacturing / co-warehouse facility in Northern Kentucky, alongside consolidating
certain existing service centers to increase manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities.

After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe that we will be better positioned to compete with Ecolab
for leadership across all markets. We believe that the combined company is best positioned to capture share on a
global scale due to Diversey’s strong existing market position, combined with our own position and track record of
sustained growth and the white space afforded by such a fragmented market.

_Food & Beverage_

Diversey is one of the only two global players in the Food & Beverage segment and competes primarily
with Ecolab. The Food & Beverage market is largely consolidated and Diversey and Ecolab together hold
approximately half of the global market share. Ecolab and Diversey generally compete within cleaning and hygiene
solutions. Other, smaller competitors exist including Zep, Reckitt and Kersia. These players tend to service more
regional markets and operate with highly limited product and distribution capabilities.

Prior to the Transactions, we entered into a distribution relationship with Diversey through which we
provide water treatment products to be marketed to Diversey’s existing customer base within its Food & Beverage
segment. This current offering sets Diversey apart from Ecolab and represents an opportunity for additional market
capture and cross-selling in the future following the consummation of the Transactions.

**_Sustainability and Environmental and Social Governance_**

We drive sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw materials waste while improving
operational productivity. Increased focus on sustainability and ESG is a key trend across both Consumer Solutions
and Industrial Solutions segments and is driving demand as our customers aim to reduce water and energy

consumption, optimize raw materials spend and reduce waste emission. These objectives require increased chemical
use which is driving increased demand for our business. Institutional products are designed to enhance cleanliness,
safety, environmental sustainability, and efficiency needed to serve our customers in the healthcare, education, food
service, retail and grocery, hospitality, and building service contractor industries. Food & Beverage solutions will
maximize food safety, operational excellence, and sustainability for our customers in the brewing, beverage, dairy,
processed foods, pharmaceutical and agriculture industries.

At the micro level, we provide solutions to customers with specific sustainability goals. For example, our
offering of PFAS-free oil and grease resistant technology has been selected by major brand owners as a replacement
in food service bowls. We also made a series of recommendations to a chemical company which resulted in a
reduction of 28,000 cubic meters of water per year and 3,000 tons of CO2 emissions. The resulting savings for our
customer were approximately $27 million per year. Further, our cal-hypo-based shocks that are sold at big-box
retailers eliminate the need to drain and refill pools due to over stabilization, resulting in potential water savings of
up to 600 gallons per pound used instead of dichlor and we estimate approximate water savings of up to 25 billion
gallons per year. Diversey’s Clax® Advanced laundry solution supports clean and bright laundry at low wash
temperatures to lower operational costs and reduce its customers’ environmental impact. Further, its delivers
excellent linen hygiene and extends linen life. Clax® Advanced provides solutions in a variety of industrial laundry
applications globally such as hotels and nursing homes, with substantial operational savings in conserving energy
and water while reducing waste. Benefits of this offering include: (1) up to a 35% reduction in water use (or 8,000
kilo liters; the equivalent of three Olympic swimming pools), (2) up to a 40% reduction in steam use (or 600 metric
tons), up to a 15% reduction in electricity use (or 5,000 kilowatt hour), (3) up to a 16% reduction in wash time (or
~150 work days), (4) up to 35% effluent (or 8,000 kilo liters), (5) up to 100 metric tons reduction in CO2 emissions
and (6) up to 30% extension in linen life. Our management is dedicated to, and focused on, building and marketing
our strong ESG reputation, shifting to green products and providing value-added services to help our customers
achieve their sustainability targets.

Focusing on solving customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges has led to notable results for
Solenis. As of September 30, 2022, (1) 86% of innovation projects in the pipeline had a sustainability / circularity

290 thousand metric tonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions.

We are also focused on long term sustainability goals for our business that include the following long term

**Competitive Strengths**

**_Leading Provider in Growing Water Intensive and Relatively Recession Resilient End Markets_**

We believe the size of Solenis’ total addressable market was $39 billion as of 2020 and that the market is
relatively fragmented, with four top players, presenting an opportunity for us to capture share. Further, we believe
the size of Diversey’s total addressable market is $46 billion. Our combined platform will create a scaled leader
across all water intensive industries. Based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, we
believe that we have the #1 market position in the Consumer Solutions segment and are one of the top market
players in the highly fragmented Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we believe we are one of two top
players in the U.S. pool and spa chemicals market. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe we will be one
of the top players in the Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage markets.

We serve a variety of growing diverse water-intensive end markets, including consumer chemicals
(estimated by a third-party expert advisor to grow at 1.8% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030), industrial
chemical (estimated by a third-party expert advisor to grow at 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025),
and pool and spa (estimated by a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market at 3%+ CAGR).
As a combined company, other end markets will include institutional (estimated by a third-party expert to grow at
over 5.3% CAGR for the four-year period 2022 to 2026) and food & beverage (estimated by a third-party expert to
grow at 6.5% CAGR for the four-year period 2022 to 2026). We have a comprehensive portfolio of solutions
including Biocides, Antifoams, Raw and Waste Water treatments, Deposit Control, Dosing & Dispensing
Equipment, proprietary owned chemical formulas among others for our customers to address their needs in these
growing end markets.

We believe that the majority of the end markets we serve are relatively recession resilient, which in
combination with our business management, will protect us from any severe impact to our profitability in the event
of an economic downturn.

**_Global Leader with Diverse Sticky Customer Base_**

After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have a large geographical footprint that enables us to
provide global service to our customers. We are present on six continents, with both laboratories and production
facilities across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets. After giving effect
to the Transactions, we will have approximately 15,600 employees with a substantial presence across the North
Americas, EMEA, and APAC regions. Our strategic global footprint allows us to efficiently and effectively serve
customers around the world by providing consistent products and service. Diversey offers further expansion
opportunities, particular given by its strength in EMEA.

Our service and technical abilities are mission critical to our customers. Typically our trained value-add
employees, scientists, and service engineers are embedded at customers’ sites, creating strong and long-term
relationships. We represent a lower overall percentage of our customers’ cost base and have been able to achieve
significant value add documented savings for our customers. We are highly engrained in our customers’ workflow,
and it is often difficult, expensive, and potentially disruptive for customers to switch to a competitor. As a result, we
believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value
proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company. After giving effect to the
Transactions, the top ten customers for the combined company are expected to represent approximately 12% of total
Net sales with the largest customer representing approximately 2% of the combined company Net sales.

**_Differentiated Business Model with Best in Class Service, Chemistry, and Technology_**

We believe our suite of comprehensive products and services unlocks customer value as a result of our
industry leading employees and innovative technology offerings. Our solutions represent a small portion of our
customers’ overall end costs and provide a significant return on investment. Our differentiated service model, with
approximately 2,400 of our sales and service engineers on site with our customers, leads to highly recurring, nondiscretionary spending on our products and services, and with our solutions and value propositions including
industry leading technology and equipment and artificial intelligence abilities, Solenis was able to achieve $179
million of value-add documented savings for our customers in the twelve months ended September 30, 2022.

We offer innovative chemistries to address customers’ operational and sustainability challenges while our
technology is at the forefront of the digitization of the water treatment industry. Further, we have product
development capabilities to meet customers’ new and evolving needs, based on three main pillars. First, we have
approximately 270 dedicated research and development professionals with two-thirds of our annual technology
spend supporting those efforts. Second, our innovation pipeline includes approximately 47 projects, representing
significant potential run-rate revenue, and features approximately 4,130 patents, including patents for chemical and
equipment technologies. In total, Solenis has 2,259 patents issued and 613 patents currently pending, while Diversey
has 1,108 patents issued and 150 patents currently pending. Lastly, our strategically located facilities around the
world focus on analyzing and diagnosing products and processes, as well as conducting testing to recommend
effective improvements that enhance both productivity and quality for our customers. This is critical as new and
innovative products carry a higher than average margin and this mix shift is expected to drive increased profitability
for our business.

**_Pricing Discipline to Drive Margin Growth_**

We have a track-record of actively monitoring and managing prices, enabling the pass-through of raw
material cost increases to maintain margins. Through Solenis’ value-documentation program, sales teams have
accountability requirements to show that at least 5% of Net sales deliver a value advantage to customers, which
enables price capture even in deflationary environments. This has enabled us to pass through a majority of increases
in raw chemical materials, which are one of the major drivers for cost inflation, to customers by adjusting prices
accordingly. We began to see a significant increase in the price of our raw materials, including ethylene and
propylene, during the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and we began to pass on price increases to our
customers. Typically, we experience an approximately 90-day lag in implementing our price increases, however,
during the six months ended March 31, 2023, we exceeded our goals and were able to drive price increases even
faster with price exceeding cost during the six months ended March 31, 2023 in all of our business segments.

While Diversey continues to adjust prices to pass through increases in raw materials costs, Diversey was
slower to react to the inflationary cost environment than Solenis, which resulted in more pronounced margin
compression throughout 2022 than Solenis. Once combined, Diversey’s performance is expected to improve as they
will operate on Solenis’ value-documentation program. Typically, Diversey experiences an approximately 90-day
lag in implementing our price increases, however, during the six months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey exceeded
its goals and was able to drive price increases even faster with Cost of goods sold inflation during the six months
ended March 31, 2023 in its Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage segments.

**_Strategically Invest in High Return Capital Expenditures Expansion_**

Our key capital expenditure projects include production capacity expansion for polyvinyl amine (“PVAM”)
at our Suffolk, Virginia facility and calcium hypochlorite (cal-hypo) at our Charleston, Tennessee and Kempton
Park, South Africa facilities. Our expansion efforts will eliminate existing capacity constraints and better position us
to capitalize on customer demand for these high-margin products. Our engineering estimates for all facilities are
underway with expansion efforts expected to be online in 2026. We expect the PVAM and cal-hypo expansions to
cost $150 million and $100 million, respectively.

A majority of our customers, especially those producing packaging and tissue and towel products, are
focused on improving strength. We are a market leader in strength chemistry, with the broadest portfolio of synthetic
strength additives like PVAM and are the leading supplier of global PVAM production. Previously PVAM was
originally sold by BASF and we acquired full commercial rights as part of 2019 merger. However, in advance of the
merger, BASF raised prices substantially, resulting in lost sales. Post integration, we refilled the pipeline and
returned the product to growth, however, in recent years, our PVAM volumes have been constrained despite
debottlenecking programs implemented and we have been unable to return to pre-BASF merger levels. Further, in
fiscal year 2022, we experienced shutdowns and product issues resulting in production allocation and customer
management challenges. To solve our capacity constraint, we are looking to build incremental capacity at our
existing Suffolk, Virginia facility, which is expected to be online by the end of 2026 that will enable us to increase
capacity by approximately 100%.

Cal-hypo is a highly concentrated source of chlorine in solid form and is a cost-effective solution primarily
used for pool sanitization and maintenance with secondary uses to disinfect water in industrial and municipal
markets. Our Solenis HTH[ TM] and Poolife[TM] offerings are cal-hypo-based shocks that eliminate the need to drain and
refill pools due to over stabilization with other benefits including minimized storage requirements, dry formulation
for shelf stability and easy handling, reduced shipping and handling costs and reduced maintenance. We are
currently experiencing capacity constraints at our Kempton Park, South Africa facility. Further, given over 50% of
global supply is produced in either China or India, importing incremental capacity is both challenging and costly.
Due to these constraints, we are looking to expand our capacity. Expansion efforts at our Kempton Park facility are
underway and are expected to be completed by fiscal year ended 2023 or 2024. Further, we are pursuing a site
selection process for additional capacity including assessing potential new locations, with the expectation that all
facilities will be online by 2026. In the interim, we will look to temporarily source incremental capacity via third
parties to pre-seed the plant which we believe will drive top line growth in the near team and insourcing savings in
the future. Following its return to the United States market, Diversey’s current management team identified potential
manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities by re-positioning and consolidating certain
existing service centers. This supply chain improvement process is referred to as “Project Mega.”

Project Mega includes a largely complete consolidation of the North American supply chain footprint
through the creation of a manufacturing plant and co-located warehouse in Northern Kentucky, as well as warehouse
consolidation in Europe. Diversey started shipping from the new Kentucky warehouse in July 2022 and is
consolidating its manufacturing capabilities into the same Kentucky facility. Further, Project Mega is consolidating
five Diversey (three Institutional and two Food & Beverage) plants into four plants (two Institutional and two Food
& Beverage) and is planning on closing two Wisconsin plants. By co-locating its main warehouse and
manufacturing capabilities, and adding more capacity to bring currently contracted volumes in-house and optimizing
freight lanes, the project is expected to drive approximately $30 million of annual cost savings. The run rate cost
savings includes $11 million related to manufacturing efficiencies from increased insourcing from contract
manufacturers, more efficient lines and fixed absorption, co-location of liquid manufacturing and wipes conversion
and an optimized flow of processes, $10 million related to logistics and the ability to avoid shipping between sites
along with having new sites closer to suppliers and customers, $7 million related to direct savings achieved from
materials sourcing using larger orders (i.e. from drums to bulk orders), $1 million related to warehousing from lower
rent and co-locating with manufacturing and $2 million related to other.

**Historical Business Segmentation**

**_Solenis_**

Since the joint venture arrangement with BASF in January 2019, Solenis’ business has principally
consisted of three operating segments: Pulp & Paper, Industrial Water, and Reverse Supply Agreements.

**_Pulp & Paper. The Pulp & Paper (“P&P”) business manufactures and sells a broad array of process_**
chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention
aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational
efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally.

In addition, the P&P business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and
writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout
and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents
and wet and dry strength additives.

**_Industrial Water. The Industrial Water (“IWT”) business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water_**
treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products
include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination,
membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the IWT business offers process additives such as frothers
and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and corrosion
inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general
manufacturing markets.

**_Reverse Supply Agreements. As part of the joint venture with BASF in January 2019, Solenis agreed to_**
provide certain finished goods to BASF, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure, intended to
allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain its retained businesses. These arrangements and related activities comprise
the Reverse Supply Agreements (“RSA”) segment of Solenis. As part of the resegmentation described below, RSA
will become part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment.

Solenis also provides automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems,
proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment
offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’
facilities. As part of the resegmentation described below, equipment destined for packaging mills will become part
of the go-forward Consumer Solutions segment. Equipment provided by refineries will form part of the go-forward
Industrial Solutions segment.

**_Sigura_**

Beginning with the quarter ended March 31, 2021 and following the divestiture of its Surface Water
business in October 2020, Sigura moved its commercial pools segment from the previous Industrial, Commercial,
Municipal & Surface Water segment (now known as Industrial & Municipal Water segment) to be consolidated with
the previous Residential Pool Segment under a newly named Pool Solutions segment. Additionally, Sigura has a
third Other segment for other operations.

**_Pools._** Sigura’s pool business offers the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and
water parks. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Pool segment had Net sales of $540 million, of
which 71% was generated in North America, 22% in EMEA and 7% in Latin America.

31


-----

    - **_Recreational Water. Sigura’s recreational pool and spa care portfolio brings clean, healthy water to_**
households worldwide with a variety of shock, sanitizers, oxidizers, algaecides and balancers. Sigura’s
trusted brands ensure clean and healthy water for its customers’ and consumers’ pools and spas across
seasons.

    - **_Commercial Pools & Spas. Sigura’s commercial pool brands have been at the cutting edge of_**
swimming pool water treatment for over 30 years. Its chlorination solutions are used worldwide for
amusement parks, community pools, hotels, resorts, and professional training venues. Sigura
specializes in powerful sanitizers, coagulants and pool maintenance products in order to deliver water
clarity, color and sparkle to customers’ pools, while ensuring the highest level of water quality, and
Sigura’s range of automated feed systems make such professional pool treatment easy to achieve.

**_Industrial & Municipal Water._** Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment offers treatment of water
for drinking, agriculture, irrigation, food processing and industrial applications. For the twelve months ended June
30, 2021, Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment had Net sales of $63 million, of which 43% was generated
in North America, 43% in EMEA and 14% in Latin America.

    - **_Industrial Water. Sigura’s Industrial segment (56% of twelve months ended June 30, 2021 total_**
segment sales) is a leading specialty chemical supplier to the global water treatment market and is also
a specialty chemical manufacturer. Sigura offers oxidizing and non-oxidizing biocides, feeders and
dosing equipment to customers for use in power plants, cooling cycles, food and beverage and the
paper industry. The combination of innovative technologies, patented solid biocide feed systems and
thorough application knowledge allows Sigura to deliver leading edge solutions to its customers’ most
demanding problems.

    - **_Municipal Water. Sigura’s Municipal segment (44% of twelve months ended June 30, 2021 total_**
segment sales) is focused on helping provide access to clean drinking water and safe water supplies,
which is fundamental to human health. Sigura’s global team of drinking water experts provide easy to
use, modular chlorination systems, designed to solve each location’s unique operational requirements.

**Prior/2021 Business Resegmentation**

Following a strategic review related to Solenis’ operating segments and in anticipation of the closing of the
Solenis Acquisition, changes were introduced in the segment reporting from October 1, 2021 onwards.

The segmentation changes were made for the following reasons: (i) to align the segment structure to ensure
that our financial reporting segments are in line with its strategic approach in demarcating its operations and (ii) to
manage the business and make business decisions based on product lines and services in the most effective manner.

Major changes to highlight included: (i) the creation of a new Pool Solutions segment to account for the
contribution of Sigura’s Pools segment, focused on delivering products for the treatment of pools, spas and water
parks, (ii) the renaming of the Pulp & Paper business as the Consumer Solutions business, (iii) the renaming of the
Industrial Water business as the Industrial Solutions business, (iv) the reallocation of the food processing aspects of
the business from the newly named Industrial Solutions business to sit with the other consumer-based products and
services within the newly named Consumer Solutions business, (v) the reallocation of the pulp processing aspects of
the business from the newly named Consumer Solutions business to sit with the other industrial-focused products
and services within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment, (vi) the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial &
Municipal Water business to the newly named Industrial Solutions segment and (vii) the inclusion of Solenis’ RSA
business within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment.

**_Consumer Solutions._** The Pulp & Paper segment of the historical Solenis business was renamed as the
Consumer Solutions segment. The Consumer Solutions segment is mostly affected by the removal of Pulp and its
reallocation to the Industrial Water segment (now renamed as the Industrial Solutions segment).

**_Industrial Solutions._** The Industrial Water segment of the historical Solenis business was renamed as the
Industrial Solutions segment. The Industrial Solutions segment is mostly affected by the inclusion of the RSA

segment, the removal of Food and its reallocation to the Pulp & Paper segment (now renamed the Consumer
Solutions segment) and the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal business.

**_Pool Solutions._** Sigura’s Pool segment, including residential and commercial pools, forms the new Pool
Solutions business segment.

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisition_**

On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to
which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a
wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. At the effective time of the Acquisition, Merger Sub will merge with and into
Diversey, with Diversey surviving the merger as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent, each issued and outstanding
share of common stock, par value $0.0001 per share of Diversey (other than dissenting shares) (the “Diversey
Common Stock”), will automatically be converted into the right to receive, in respect of shareholders other than
BCPE (the controlling shareholder of Diversey and an affiliate of Bain Capital), $8.40 per share, and, in respect of
BCPE $7.84 per share, in each case, without interest and less any applicable withholding taxes and BCPE will also
rollover a portion of its Diversey Common Stock into an affiliate of the Sponsor, and each share of Diversey
Common Stock will be cancelled, cease to be outstanding and cease to exist, and the Diversey shareholders will
cease to have any other rights with respect to their Diversey Common Stock. Parent will be deemed to be the
accounting acquirer for purposes of the Transactions.

The purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through:

    - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby;

    - borrowings under a new tranche of the Term Loan;

    - the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment; and

    - the New Equity Contribution.

For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of
Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” and “Description of Notes.”

The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various customary closing conditions, including, among
others, (i) the affirmative vote in favor of adoption of the Acquisition Agreement by holders of at least two thirds of
the shares of Diversey Common Stock then outstanding and entitled to vote thereon, (ii) the expiration or early
termination of the waiting periods under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act (the “HSR Act”), (iii)
the absence of any order of any court of competent jurisdiction or other legal or regulatory restraint or prohibition
preventing the consummation of the Acquisition or enjoining or prohibiting the consummation of the Acquisition
that continues to be in effect, (iv) completion of any required information and/or consultation on procedures with a
labor organization, (v) the absence of a Company Material Adverse Effect (as defined in the Acquisition
Agreement), (vi) the accuracy of the representations and warranties contained in the Acquisition Agreement (subject
to certain materiality qualifications), (vii) compliance with the covenants and agreements contained in the
Acquisition Agreement and (viii) obtaining certain specified regulatory approvals.

The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights, including the right to terminate if the
Acquisition has not been consummated by the Outside Date. The Acquisition Agreement also contains customary
representations, warranties and covenants.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively,
reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin.
