In addition, the Intercreditor Agreements will provide that so long as any obligations under the Credit
Agreements are outstanding, in the event of a bankruptcy, the holders of the Notes will be subject to certain
restrictions with respect to their ability to object to various motions or seek other relief with respect to the Collateral
on a number of important matters. In particular, the ABL Intercreditor Agreement will also prohibit the holders of
the Notes from proposing, voting for, or otherwise directly or indirectly supporting any plan of reorganization or
similar dispositive restructuring plan that is inconsistent with the priorities or other provisions of the ABL
Intercreditor Agreement, and the holders of the Notes may under certain circumstances be required to turn over
amounts and/or distributions they may receive in respect of the Current Asset Collateral to the holders of obligations
under the ABL Revolving Credit Facility. See “—The rights of holders of the Notes in the Current Asset Collateral
may be adversely affected by the ABL Intercreditor Agreement.” Also, the Pari Passu Intercreditor Agreement will
impose limitations on the holders of the Notes with respect to their rights to object to proposed DIP financing or the
use of cash collateral that has been consented to by the lenders under the Term Loan Credit Agreement and that
satisfy certain terms and conditions. See “Description of Notes—Brief Description of the Notes—Security—
Intercreditor Arrangements—Pari Passu Intercreditor Agreement.” After such a bankruptcy filing, the value of the
Collateral securing the Notes could materially deteriorate, and the holders of the Notes may be unable to raise
various objections or take other actions. The right of the holders of the obligations under the ABL Revolving Credit
Facility to foreclose upon and sell the Current Asset Collateral or of the holders of the obligations under the Term
Loan Credit Agreement to foreclose upon and sell the Fixed Asset Collateral upon the occurrence of an event of
default also would be subject to limitations under applicable bankruptcy laws if we or any of our subsidiaries
become subject to a bankruptcy proceeding.

Furthermore, in the event the bankruptcy court determines that the value of the Collateral is not sufficient
to repay all amounts due on the Notes (after taking into account all other obligations that are secured by liens that
are either pari passu with or senior to the liens securing the Notes on the various components of the Collateral), the
holders of the Notes would have “undersecured deficiency claims” as to the difference. Federal bankruptcy laws do
not permit the payment or accrual of post-petition interest, costs, expenses, and attorneys’ fees to the holders of
“undersecured claims” (or of unsecured claims) during the debtor’s bankruptcy case. Other consequences of a
finding of under-collateralization would include, among other things, a lack of entitlement to receive “adequate
protection” under federal bankruptcy laws with respect to the unsecured, deficiency portion of the Notes. In
addition, if any payments of post-petition interest had been made prior to or at the time of such a finding of undercollateralization, those payments could be recharacterized by the bankruptcy court as a reduction of the principal
amount of the Notes.

As a result, bankruptcy laws may act to limit the ability of the holders of the Notes to realize upon the
Collateral and to receive post-bankruptcy interest, fees, expenses or “adequate protection” with respect to any
unsecured, deficiency portion of the Notes.

**_Prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, if the Escrow Issuer becomes subject to bankruptcy proceedings,_**
**_the escrowed funds might be deemed to be property of the bankruptcy estate, and the holders of the Notes might_**
**_become unsecured creditors._**

If the Escrow Issuer commences a bankruptcy or reorganization case in the United States, or one is
commenced against the Escrow Issuer, U.S. bankruptcy law may prevent the Trustee under the Indenture from using
the escrowed funds to fund the special mandatory redemption. The court adjudicating the Escrow Issuer’s
bankruptcy or reorganization case might find that the escrowed funds are property of the Escrow Issuer’s bankruptcy
estate. If it makes such a determination, the court could authorize the use of these funds by the bankruptcy estate or
the bankruptcy trustee, if one is appointed, with or without restrictions, and the Trustee would be prohibited from
using or disposing of these funds. Although the Escrow Issuer will grant a first-priority lien on the escrowed funds
in favor of the Trustee and the holders of the applicable series of Notes, unless otherwise provided with protections
in connection with such use, the holders of the Notes could become unsecured creditors of the bankruptcy estate by
virtue of the Escrow Issuer utilizing the escrowed funds during the bankruptcy or reorganization case thereby
dissipating the collateral of the holders of the Notes. Under applicable bankruptcy law, creditors, including the
holders of the Notes while the funds are held in escrow, are prohibited from foreclosing upon or disposing of a

99


-----

debtor’s property without prior bankruptcy court approval (which may not be given under the circumstances). As a
result, the holders of the Notes may not be able to have the escrowed funds applied at the time or in the manner
contemplated by the Indenture and could suffer a loss. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special
Mandatory Redemption.”

In addition, even if the bankruptcy court recognizes that the holders of Notes are secured creditors with a
first-priority lien on the escrowed funds, it could nevertheless permit the use of the escrowed funds in exchange for
“adequate protection” of the holders’ interest in such funds. It is not clear what adequate protection, if any, the
bankruptcy court might require, but it is possible that the bankruptcy court could allow the use of the escrowed
funds and provide the holders with adequate protection that may not be as valuable as the escrowed funds, such as
replacement liens on different and less liquid collateral.

**_If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, between the time of the issuance of the Notes_**
**_and the consummation of the Acquisition, the parties to the Acquisition Agreement may agree to modify or waive_**
**_the terms or conditions of such document without the consent of the holders of the Notes._**

The parties to the Acquisition Agreement may agree to amendments or waivers of, or consents to
departures or deviations from, the terms thereof, and holders of the Notes will not have the ability to veto any such
actions. The Escrow Agreement will not preclude the transaction parties from making such modifications or
waivers, and such modifications or waivers will not be made in consultation with the Trustee, the Escrow Agent, the
initial purchasers or holders of the Notes. In addition, your decision to invest in the Notes will be made prior to the
consummation of the Acquisition, and completion of the certain closing conditions stated in the Acquisition
Agreement, and consequently you will not be afforded protection with respect to changes in the business or financial
condition of the acquired business following the closing of this offering that would have a material adverse effect on
our business. Although no such amendment, waiver or consent is presently contemplated, if the parties to the
Acquisition Agreement decide to make changes to the terms thereof (including to the purchase price) or to waive
conditions thereunder, the holders of the Notes will not be able to prevent the release of the escrowed property to
fund the Acquisition as a result of any such action or object to any such amendment and will not have any veto or
consent rights in respect of any such actions.

**_If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied,_**
**_the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indenture_**
**_has or would have occurred and is continuing._**

The escrowed funds will be released from escrow and utilized as described under “Use of Proceeds” upon
the Escrow Issuer’s delivery to the Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release
of the proceeds from escrow have been satisfied. The escrowed funds will be released from escrow even if a default
or event of default under the Indenture has occurred and is continuing.

**THE TRANSACTIONS**

**The Acquisition**

On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to
which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a
wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. At the effective time of the Acquisition, Merger Sub will merge with and into
Diversey, with Diversey surviving the merger as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent, each issued and outstanding
share of common stock, par value $0.0001 per share of Diversey (other than dissenting shares) (the “Diversey
Common Stock”), will automatically be converted into the right to receive, in respect of shareholders other than
BCPE (the controlling shareholder of Diversey and an affiliate of Bain Capital), $8.40 per share, and, in respect of
BCPE $7.84 per share, in each case, without interest and less any applicable withholding taxes and BCPE will also
rollover a portion of its Diversey Common Stock into an affiliate of the Sponsor, and each share of Diversey
Common Stock will be cancelled, cease to be outstanding and cease to exist, and the Diversey shareholders will
cease to have any other rights with respect to their Diversey Common Stock. Parent will be deemed to be the
accounting acquirer for purposes of the Transactions.

The purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through:

    - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby;

    - borrowings under a new tranche of the Term Loan;

    - the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment; and

    - the New Equity Contribution.

For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of
Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” and “Description of Notes.”

The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various customary closing conditions, including, among
others, (i) the affirmative vote in favor of adoption of the Acquisition Agreement by holders of at least two thirds of
the shares of Diversey Common Stock then outstanding and entitled to vote thereon, (ii) the expiration or early
termination of the waiting periods under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act (the “HSR Act”), (iii)
the absence of any order of any court of competent jurisdiction or other legal or regulatory restraint or prohibition
preventing the consummation of the Acquisition or enjoining or prohibiting the consummation of the Acquisition
that continues to be in effect, (iv) completion of any required information and/or consultation on procedures with a
labor organization, (v) the absence of a Company Material Adverse Effect (as defined in the Acquisition
Agreement), (vi) the accuracy of the representations and warranties contained in the Acquisition Agreement (subject
to certain materiality qualifications), (vii) compliance with the covenants and agreements contained in the
Acquisition Agreement and (viii) obtaining certain specified regulatory approvals.

The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights, including the right to terminate if the
Acquisition has not been consummated by the Outside Date. The Acquisition Agreement also contains customary
representations, warranties and covenants.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively,
reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin.

**_The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release_**

This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes prior
to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will issue the Notes and deposit (or cause to be
deposited) the gross proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts
pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series
of Notes will be secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and

101


-----

investments therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Unless the Acquisition
closes substantially concurrently with, or prior to, this offering, substantially concurrently with the consummation of
the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will consummate the Escrow Merger, pursuant to which it will merge with and
into the Ultimate Issuer, with the Ultimate Issuer ultimately continuing as the surviving entity. Assuming the Escrow
Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will
become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to
exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the
Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors.

The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event
of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indenture. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and
Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release
Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of
default under the Indenture has or would have occurred and is continuing.”

In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time
prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Escrow Issuer’s good faith judgment, to
be incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date, or (c) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the
Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each series
of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such
series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such special
mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—In the event that the
Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the
Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect
on the applicable series of Notes.”

The escrowed funds will be limited to the gross proceeds from this offering of the Notes, together with any
earnings thereon and investments thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest
on the Notes that may be payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. The Ultimate Issuer or one of its
affiliates will issue the Equity Commitment Letter to the Escrow Issuer, for the benefit of the Trustee, the Escrow
Agent and the holders of the Notes, to transfer to the Escrow Issuer an amount necessary to fund the payment of
accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes in the event of a special mandatory redemption, plus certain fees and
expenses.

If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will
not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum.

For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see “Description
of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

**_The Refinancing_**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release
Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using proceeds from the Notes, borrowings under a new
incremental tranche of the Term Loan Facility, the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment and the New Equity
Contribution.

**_The Credit Facilities_**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release
Conditions, the Issuer intends to borrow an incremental $750 million tranche under the Term Loan Facility and to
increase the available capacity under its ABL Revolving Credit Facility to provide for borrowings of up to $700
million, subject to borrowing base capacity.

102


-----

**_New Equity Contribution and New Perpetual Preferred Equity_**

As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund a portion of the New Equity Contribution of
approximately $950 million in cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which will, through a series of transactions,
ultimately be contributed to Parent and which will be used as part of the consideration to be paid in connection with
the Acquisition. In addition as part of the Acquisition, BCPE will rollover: (i) approximately $617 million of its
existing equity interests in Diversey into common units in an indirect parent of Parent as part of the New Equity
Contribution; and (ii) approximately $438 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into preferred units in
an indirect parent of Parent as the New Perpetual Preferred Equity, in each case, in satisfaction of a portion of the
consideration payable to BCPE under the Acquisition. From the Acquisition Closing Date until the first anniversary
thereof, Platinum or its affiliates may acquire the New Perpetual Preferred Equity from BCPE. Platinum may
exercise this option in its sole discretion following the closing of the Transactions.

**NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS**

**Note 1 — Description of the Transactions**

**Acquisition**

On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to
which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a
wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. At the effective time of the Acquisition, each issued and outstanding share of
common stock, par value $0.0001 per share of Diversey (other than dissenting shares) (the “Diversey Common
Stock”), will automatically be converted into the right to receive, in respect of shareholders other than BCPE (the
controlling shareholder of Diversey and an affiliate of Bain Capital), $8.40 per share, and, in respect of BCPE $7.84
per share, in each case, without interest and less any applicable withholding taxes and BCPE will also rollover a
portion of its Diversey Common Stock into an affiliate of the Sponsor, and each share of Diversey Common Stock
will be cancelled, cease to be outstanding and cease to exist, and the Diversey shareholders will cease to have any
other rights with respect to their Diversey Common Stock. Parent will be deemed to be the accounting acquirer for
purposes of the Transactions.

The purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through:

    - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby;

    - borrowings under a new tranche of the Term Loan;

    - the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment; and

    - the New Equity Contribution.

For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of
Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” and “Description of Notes.”

The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various customary closing conditions, including, among
others, (i) the affirmative vote in favor of adoption of the Acquisition Agreement by holders of at least two thirds of
the shares of Diversey Common Stock then outstanding and entitled to vote thereon, (ii) the expiration or early
termination of the waiting periods under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act (the “HSR Act”), (iii)
the absence of any order of any court of competent jurisdiction or other legal or regulatory restraint or prohibition
preventing the consummation of the Acquisition or enjoining or prohibiting the consummation of the Acquisition
that continues to be in effect, (iv) completion of any required information and/or consultation on procedures with a
labor organization, (v) the absence of a Company Material Adverse Effect (as defined in the Acquisition
Agreement), (vi) the accuracy of the representations and warranties contained in the Acquisition Agreement (subject
to certain materiality qualifications), (vii) compliance with the covenants and agreements contained in the
Acquisition Agreement and (viii) obtaining certain specified regulatory approvals.

The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights, including the right to terminate if the
Acquisition has not been consummated by the Outside Date. The Acquisition Agreement also contains customary
representations, warranties and covenants.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After
the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively,
reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin.

**_The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release_**

This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes prior
to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will issue the Notes and deposit (or cause to be
deposited) the gross proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts
pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series
of Notes will be secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and
investments therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Unless the Acquisition
closes substantially concurrently with, or prior to, this offering, substantially concurrently with the consummation of

112


-----

the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will consummate the Escrow Merger, pursuant to which it will merge with and
into the Ultimate Issuer, with the Ultimate Issuer ultimately continuing as the surviving entity. Assuming the Escrow
Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will
become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to
exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the
Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors.

The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event
of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indenture. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and
Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release
Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of
default under the Indenture has or would have occurred and is continuing.”

In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time
prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Escrow Issuer’s good faith judgment, to
be incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date, or (c) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the
Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each series
of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such
series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such special
mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—In the event that the
Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the
Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect
on the applicable series of Notes.”

The escrowed funds will be limited to the gross proceeds from this offering of the Notes, together with any
earnings thereon and investments thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest
on the Notes that may be payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. The Ultimate Issuer or one of its
affiliates will issue the Equity Commitment Letter to the Escrow Issuer, for the benefit of the Trustee, the Escrow
Agent and the holders of the Notes, to transfer to the Escrow Issuer an amount necessary to fund the payment of
accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes in the event of a special mandatory redemption, plus certain fees and
expenses.

If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will
not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum.

For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see “Description
of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

**_The Refinancing_**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release
Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using proceeds from the Notes, borrowings under a new
incremental tranche of the Term Loan Facility, the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment and the New Equity
Contribution.

**_The Credit Facilities_**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release
Conditions, the Issuer intends to borrow an incremental $750 million tranche under the Term Loan Facility and to
increase the available capacity under its ABL Revolving Credit Facility to provide for borrowings of up to $700
million, subject to borrowing base capacity.

**_New Equity Contribution and New Perpetual Preferred Equity_**

As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund a portion of the New Equity Contribution of
approximately $950 million in cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which will, through a series of transactions,
ultimately be contributed to Parent and which will be used as part of the consideration to be paid in connection with
the Acquisition. In addition as part of the Acquisition, BCPE will rollover: (i) approximately $617 million of its
existing equity interests in Diversey into common units in an indirect parent of Parent as part of the New Equity
Contribution; and (ii) approximately $438 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into preferred units in

113


-----

an indirect parent of Parent as the New Perpetual Preferred Equity, in each case, in satisfaction of a portion of the
consideration payable to BCPE under the Acquisition. From the Acquisition Closing Date until the first anniversary
thereof, Platinum or its affiliates may acquire the New Perpetual Preferred Equity from BCPE. Platinum may
exercise this option in its sole discretion following the closing of the Transactions.

**Note 2 — Basis of Presentation**

The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information was prepared using the
acquisition method of accounting in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Topic 805,
Business Combinations (“ASC 805”), and using the fair value concepts defined in ASC Topic 820, Fair Value
Measurement (“ASC 820”) and based on the historical consolidated financial statements of Solenis and Diversey.
Under ASC 805, all Solenis assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination are recognized and
measured at their assumed acquisition date fair value, while transaction costs and restructuring costs associated with
the business combination are expensed as incurred. The excess of merger consideration over the fair value of assets
acquired and liabilities assumed, if any, is allocated to goodwill.

The allocation of the purchase consideration for the Acquisition depends upon certain estimates and
assumptions, all of which are preliminary. The allocation of the purchase consideration has been made for the
purpose of developing the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information. A final
determination of fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed relating to the Acquisition could differ
materially from the preliminary allocation of the purchase consideration. This final valuation will be based on the
actual net tangible and intangible assets of Solenis and Diversey existing at the acquisition date. Pursuant to the
terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is expected to close the month in which all the requisite closing
conditions have been satisfied. The final valuation may materially change the allocation of the purchase
consideration, which could materially affect the fair values assigned to the assets and liabilities and could result in a
material change to the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information.

The transaction accounting adjustments represent management’s best estimates and are based upon
currently available information and certain assumptions that management believes are reasonable under the
circumstances.

The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information presented is for illustrative
purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the financial position or results of operations that would have been
realized if the Acquisition had been completed on the dates indicated, nor is it indicative of future operating results
or financial position.

We have undertaken a preliminary review of both Solenis’ and Diversey’s accounting policies and did not
identify any significant adjustments that would be required to be made in order to conform the accounting policies
of the companies.

**Overview**

Solenis is a leading supplier of specialty chemicals and services to the pulp and paper, mining, food and
beverage, power generation, refining, chemical processing, general manufacturing, municipal and pools markets. It
offers chemical and equipment technologies and services designed to help customers improve operational
efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact.

To meet the diverse requirements of its customers, Solenis offers a range of services, including start-up and
ongoing applications support, analytical and applications laboratories and customized program offerings.

Solenis’ products include biocides, cleaners, coagulants and flocculants, converting additives, corrosion
inhibitors, defoamers, deposit control agents, food and beverage processing aids, internal and surface size agents,
membrane treatments, mining and mineral processing aids, monitoring and control systems, odor inhibitors and
neutralizers, oxygen scavengers, polyacrylamides, pulp mill additives, retention, drainage and clarification aids,
scale inhibitors, sludge dewatering polymers, surface treatments, tissue making additives, wet- and dry-strength
additives, colorants, surface size, antiscalants for desalination, and wood adhesives.

Within the pools market (via the legacy Sigura business), Solenis is a leading supplier of sanitizers and
other water treatment solutions featuring top consumer brands in residential and commercial pool and industrial
water care markets.

As of March 31, 2023, Solenis had 49 manufacturing facilities in 22 countries. Parent markets and
distributes its products and services directly and through third-party distributors in the Americas, Europe, the Middle
East, Africa and Asia Pacific.

Solenis’ business principally consists of three operating segments: (1) Consumer, (2) Industrial (which
integrates Solenis’ prior Industrial Water business and the operating results of its reverse supply agreements with
BASF as well as Sigura’s Industrial business) and (3) Pools. A brief description for each of these operating segments
is as follows:

Consumer Solutions – The Consumer Solutions business manufactures and sells a broad array of process
chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention
aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational
efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally. In
addition, the Consumer Solutions business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing
and writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid
holdout and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing
agents and wet and dry strength additives.

Industrial Solutions – The Industrial Solutions business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water
treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products
include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination,
membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the Industrial Solutions business offers process additives
such as frothers and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and
corrosion inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and
general manufacturing markets. The Industrial Solutions business includes the operating results of Solenis’ reverse
supply agreements through which Solenis agreed via the joint venture with BASF to provide certain finished goods

126


-----

to BASF at below-market prices, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure. Such agreements are
intended to allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain the businesses that BASF retained after the joint venture between
Solenis and BASF which were previously serviced by BASF Paper & Water.

Pools - The Pool Solutions business offers water care products and value-added services offered for
residential and commercial pools and spas in consumer channels such as Mass Retail, Professional Dealer and
Commercial and services top consumer brands in pool care markets. Key brands include, but are not limited to
HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, Sirona Spa Care®, and HTH Spa®.

Solenis also manufactures and supplies automated equipment, including performance-based feed and
control systems, proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and
equipment offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at
customers’ facilities.

**Factors Affecting Our Operating Results**

The following discussion sets forth certain components of our statements of operation as well as factors
that impact those items:

**_Net sales_**

We generate revenue from the sale of products and services within each of the four geographic markets that
we serve. Our Net sales represents gross revenue net of estimates for returns and price allowances. Price allowances
are inclusive of discounts for prompt payment, customer specific rebates, continuous improvement rebates, and
other volume based incentives. Our overall Net sales are impacted by the following factors:

    - Fluctuations in overall economic activity within the geographic markets that we serve;

    - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates;

    - Changes in the prices charged for products and services;

    - Changes in the overall volume of customers served based on underlying fluctuations in supply and
demand;

    - Changes in the level of competition in the marketplace, either via price, or the launch of new products
by competitors;

    - Changes in the application or applied usage of our products and services; and

    - Sales and amortization of reverse supply agreements acquired as part of the acquisition of BASF Paper
& Water.

**_Cost of sales_**

Our Cost of sales consists primarily of the following:

    - _Materials and production costs: We purchase raw materials from a global network of suppliers to_
support the production of finished products and the delivery of services;

    - _Employee Costs: To retain the talent necessary to deliver high-quality products and services, we incur_
significant employee compensation and benefits costs. Payroll costs recognized via Cost of sales relate
specifically to those employees involved in the manufacturing process;

    - _Depreciation and Amortization Expense: Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost and_
depreciated based on their estimated useful lives. Acquired property, plant and equipment and definitelived intangible assets are recognized at their acquired fair values and amortized over their respective
useful lives. Assets specifically related to the production of goods and services such as an allocated
portion of costs incurred for our plant and buildings, and machine and equipment as well as
amortization expense relative to patents, process know-how and supply agreements are recognized via
_Cost of sales; and_

127


-----

    - _Other: Remaining Cost of sales relates to freight costs, warehousing expenses, costs associated with_
the idling of production facilities, product claims, or other general manufacturing costs.

Our overall Cost of sales is impacted by the following factors:

    - Changes in the price of raw materials, i.e. deflationary or inflationary price changes in the costs of
commodities;

    - Production volumes and utilization;

    - Improvement in production efficiency or other post-acquisition process improvements or cost savings
initiatives; and

    - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

**_Selling, general and administrative expense_**

Our Selling, general and administrative expense consists of all expenditures incurred in connection with the
sales and marketing of our products and services, in addition to general and administrative costs, including:

    - Compensation and benefits costs for management, including stock-based compensation expenses;

    - Expenses relating to sales personnel primarily resulting from increases or decreases in sales volume or
to meet changes in anticipated demand;

    - Expenses related to support functions and executives;

    - Depreciation expense excluding that recognized via Cost of sales in addition to other general selling
expenses incurred in the normal course of business; and

    - Service cost on our pension and other post-employment benefit plans.

Changes in our Selling, general and administrative expense as a percentage of Net sales are primarily
driven by:

    - Variances in sales volume, as fixed costs can be spread to higher sales totals;

    - Changes in demand which can impact our determinations of budgeted costs necessary to both maintain
our customer base and increase our gross revenue on a constant currency basis;

    - Frequency and depth of product launches or entrances and exits into market or geographical segments;
and

    - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

**_Research and development expense_**

Our Research and development expense represents costs incurred to develop new products or services, or
those incurred to develop and improve upon existing products or processes.

**_Amortization of intangibles_**

Amortization of intangibles represents the ratable recognition of expense relative to acquired definite-life
intangible assets that were initially recorded at fair value. This expense is exclusive of amortization recognized
through Cost of sales. Expense incurred and recognized via Amortization of intangibles primarily relates to assets
that are not directly related to revenue generating activities, i.e. customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames,
and land use rights.

128


-----

**_Restructuring and severance expense_**

Our Restructuring and severance expense relates to costs incurred for implemented reductions in force and
strategic restructuring decisions designed to reduce overall spend and better align the personnel and leadership with
our organizational structure.

**_Impairment of goodwill and intangible assets_**

We perform impairment assessments at least annually relative to any acquired goodwill and indefinite-lived
intangible assets, including in-process research and development assets. Additionally, we assess definite-lived
intangible assets for impairment to determine whether a qualitative or quantitative triggering event has occurred.

**_Acquisition and transaction-related expenses_**

We continually seek opportunities to improve upon our market position and gain synergies via business
combinations. Acquisitions and transaction-related expenses represent costs incurred from completed, in-process, or
abandoned mergers and acquisition opportunities primarily for due diligence and valuation efforts.

**_Other operating (income) expense, net_**

We recognize Other operating (income) expense, net as a result of income and expense realized in the
ordinary course of our operations, but are not classified as expense types identified above. Examples include
realized foreign exchange gains on operational transactions and gains and losses on sales of property, plant, and
equipment, as well as bank fees and other financial costs.

**_Non-operating expense (income), net_**

We recognize Non-operating expense (income), net as a result of income and expense which arise from
transactions or other items which give rise to income or expense which are not in the ordinary course of our
operations. Such items include the following:

    - Unrealized foreign exchange gains and losses;

    - Our share of income from our joint ventures accounted for under the equity method of accounting net
of distributions;

    - Royalty income;

    - Pension expense (excluding Service cost, which is included in Selling, general and administrative
expense); and

    - Adjustments in the value of tax indemnification assets.

Other items which influence Non-operating expense (income), net include certain non-recurring items
which are not related to our operations such as:

    - Gains and losses on foreign currency forward contracts; and

    - Gains and losses on extinguishment of debt.

**_Interest expense_**

Interest expense primarily relates to costs incurred for interest expense on our external borrowings and
other long-term liabilities. Other elements included in interest expense include:

    - Amortization of deferred financing costs incurred in connection with our external debt borrowings and
ABL Revolving Credit Facility;

    - Accretion of original issue discount on our external debt;

    - Interest expense on our note payable to our shareholders; and

129


-----

    - Reclassifications from Other comprehensive income related to our interest rate swaps.

**_Income tax provision_**

We are subject to income tax in the various jurisdictions in which we operate. Though the extent of our
future tax liabilities is uncertain, changes to our corporate structure, capitalization and future acquisitions are all
factors which may impact future book and taxable income of our subsidiaries and Parent as a whole. Our effective
tax rate fluctuates from period to period due to changes in the mix of income or losses in jurisdictions with a wide
range of tax rates, permanent differences between U.S. GAAP and local tax laws, and certain one-time items
including tax rate changes, benefit of non-U.S. taxes, and adjustments related to unremitted earnings of our
subsidiaries. The amortization and increased interest expense related to our acquisitions and capital structure reduces
our profit before tax to a level where the effective tax rate is highly sensitive.

_Net sales_

compared to Net sales of $1.03 billion for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase in Net sales was
primarily driven by the September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon and price increases to help offset inflationary raw
material costs. These increases were offset by declines in sales volume and unfavorable foreign currency effects.

_Cost of sales_

Cost of sales increased by $46.9 million, to $836.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as
compared to Cost of sales of $789.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. This increase was driven

primarily by the September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon and incremental raw material inflation between periods.
These increases were offset by declines in sales volume and favorable foreign currency effects.

_Selling, general and administrative expense_

Selling, general and administrative expense increased by $4.8 million to $174.0 million for the three
months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $169.2 million for the
three months ended March 31, 2022. The overall increase in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven
primarily by incremental costs related to our September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon.

_Research and development expense_

_Overview_

The following narrative compares eleven months of activity for the Successor period ended September 30,
2022 vs. the twelve months of activity for the Predecessor year ended September 30, 2021. The eleven month versus
twelve month comparison is driven by the timing of the Solenis Acquisition which closed on November 9, 2021.

_Net sales_

Net sales increased by $921.1 million to $3.91 billion for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022
as compared to Net sales of $2.99 billion for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Net sales was
driven by the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021. Net sales for the Sigura business during the eleven month
period ending September 30, 2022 were $692.2 million. Incremental Net sales on a fully comparative basis were
driven primarily by price increases to offset the impact of raw material inflation as well as increases in organically
generated volume.

_Cost of sales_

134


-----

Cost of sales increased by $900.1 million to $3.02 billion for the Successor period ended September 30,
2022, as compared to Cost of sales of $2.12 billion for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Cost of
sales driven by the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021. Cost of sales for the Sigura business during the
eleven month period ending September 30, 2021 were $463.8 million. Incremental Cost of sales on a fully
comparative basis were driven primarily by raw material cost increases as well as increases in organically generated
volume.

_Selling, general and administrative expense_

Selling, general and administrative expense increased by $89.9 million to $611.2 million for the Successor
period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $521.3 million for
the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven
primarily by the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021, inclusive of realized cost synergies and the related costs
to realize those synergies. Incremental Selling, general and administrative expense on a fully comparative basis
were driven primarily by market based compensation increases for Solenis; legacy employees.

_Research and development expense_

Research and development expense increased by $3.8 million for the Successor period ended September
30, 2022, as compared for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Research and development expense
was driven primarily the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021 and the related research and development costs
required to support the legacy Pools business.

_Amortization of intangible assets_

Amortization of intangible assets increased by $65.0 million to $114.9 million for the Successor period
ended September 30, 2022, as compared to $49.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in the
Amortization of intangible assets is primarily driven by incremental depreciation and amortization expense resulting
from the recognition of the purchase price allocations specific to the Acquisition of the heritage Solenis business and
the Sigura Contribution.

_Acquisition and transaction-related expenses_

Acquisition and transaction-related expenses increased by $31.2 million to expense of $51.1 million for the
Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to Acquisition and transaction related expenses of $19.9
million for the year ended September 30, 2021. This increase is specific to the deal costs incurred by Solenis (as
seller) and Parent (as buyer) to facilitate the closing of the Solenis Acquisition dated November 9, 2021 which
includes bank success fees as well as legal and other professional service fees incurred throughout the diligence
process.

_Other operating expense, net_

Other operating expense, net decreased from expense of $19.8 million for the year ended September 30,
2021 to expense of $9.7 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022. Fluctuations in Other operating
expense, net were primarily related to Realized foreign exchange gains and losses related to our operations.

_Non-operating (income), net_

Non-operating (income), net, increased from income of $7.2 million for the year ended September 30,
2021, to income of $257.3 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022. Incremental Non-operating
(income) was primarily driven by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates specific to our Euro-denominated
external debt which resulted in incremental income of $224.0 million between periods. Remaining net losses
incurred during the year ended September 30, 2022 driven primarily by the settlement of various monetary positions
in connection with the Acquisition and Contribution primarily offset net losses incurred during the year ended
September 30, 2021 driven primarily by the deconsolidation of our subsidiary in Trinidad and Tobago.

_Interest expense_

Interest expense increased by $36.2 million driven primarily by incremental indebtedness utilized to
finance the Acquisition and Contribution, offset by net reductions in weighted average interest rates driven primarily
by fixed rate borrowings via the Secured and Unsecured Notes.

The income tax provision increased by $41.0 million to $66.4 million for the Successor period ended

losses in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences between GAAP and local tax laws, and

as compared to Net sales of $2,753.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. The increase in Net sales was
primarily driven by increases in sales volume (inclusive of acquisitions), the effect of fluctuations in foreign
currency exchange rates and increases in pricing which increased Net sales by $106 million, $84 million and $48
million, respectively.

_Cost of sales_

2021, as compared to Cost of sales of $1,939.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. The increase in Cost
of sales was primarily attributable to the impact of raw material inflation, incremental sales volume (inclusive
acquisitions) and fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, which increased Cost of sales by $66 million, $65
million and $63 million, respectively. These increases were primarily offset by changes in sales mix, which reduced
Cost of sales by $16 million.

year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $537.0 million for
the year ended September 30, 2020. The overall decrease in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven
by permanent cost reduction programs actioned in 2020 which resulted in a net decrease in Selling, general and

**Non-GAAP Financial Metrics**

To supplement our financial information presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we use the following
non-GAAP financial measures to clarify and enhance an understanding of past performance: EBITDA, Segment
profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows. We believe that the presentation of
these financial measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our financial performance. We further believe that
these financial measures are useful financial metrics to assess our operating performance from period-to-period by
excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core business. We use certain of these financial
measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our performance relative to that of our competitors. We
utilize Segment profit as the primary measure of our segment specific performance.

**_Reconciliation of Net income (loss) to EBITDA and Segment profit_**

EBITDA consists of net income (loss) before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Segment profit
consists of EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-operating income or expense, (ii) the impact of certain non-cash, nonrecurring or other items that are included in net income (loss) and EBITDA that we do not consider indicative of our
ongoing operating performance, and (iii) certain unusual or non-recurring items impacting results in a particular
period. We believe that making such adjustments provides investors with meaningful information to understand our
operating results and ability to analyze financial and business trends on a period-to-period basis.

We believe these financial measures are commonly used by investors to evaluate our performance and that
of our competitors. However, our use of the terms EBITDA and Segment profit may vary from that of others in our
industry. These financial measures should not be considered alternatives to income before income taxes, net income
(loss), or any other performance measures derived in accordance with U.S. GAAP as measures of operating
performance.

EBITDA and Segment profit have limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in
isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under U.S. GAAP. Some of these limitations are:

EBITDA and Segment profit:

    - Do not reflect the significant interest costs relative to our external debt;

    - Eliminate the impact of income taxes from the results of our operations;

    - Although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and
amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and EBITDA and Segment profit do not reflect
any expenditures for such replacements; and

143


-----

    - Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA or Segment profit differently than we do,
limiting their usefulness as comparative measures.

We compensate for these limitations by using EBITDA and Segment profit along with other comparative
tools, together with U.S. GAAP measurements, to assist in the evaluation of operating performance. Such U.S.
GAAP measurements include income before income taxes, and net income (loss) amongst other performance
metrics.

In evaluating these financial measures, readers should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses
similar to those eliminated in this presentation. Our presentation of EBITDA and Segment profit should not be
construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items.

**_Reconciliation of Cash Flows_**

Adjusted net operating cash flows and Adjusted net investing cash flows consists of reported Net cash
(used in) provided by operating activities and Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities, each adjusted for
the effects of cash subsequently received as part of our Accounts Receivable Facility. ASU 2016-15 requires us to
evaluate the transfer of title of receivables sold under the Accounts Receivable Facility against cash received on
previously-sold receivables in exchange for the transfer of title. Since there is a dichotomy between when we legally
transfer title of receivables to ING Luxembourg S.A. (“ING”) or MUFG Bank, Ltd. (“MUFG”) under the ING
Receivables Purchasing Agreement or MUFG Receivables Purchasing Agreement, respectively, and when the cash
received on previously-sold receivables, receivables are deemed transferred in exchange for a beneficial interest in
the collection of that receivable. This is considered a non-cash investing activity. Furthermore, ultimate receipts of

144


-----

cash, when settled with ING or MUFG (as relevant), are considered cash flows from investing activities, as the
receipt is considered a return of capital on the beneficial interest.

We believe that this may cause Net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and Net cash provided
by (used in) investing activities to be potentially misleading to investors. While we do not retain legal ownership of
the receivables sold, the nature, timing, and extent of cash flows have not materially changed as a result of the
agreement. We use these Non-GAAP metrics to assess our own liquidity.

**Overview**

We are a global leading provider of high-performance hygiene, infection prevention and cleaning solutions.
We develop mission-critical products, services and technologies that save lives and protect our environment. We
were formed as an exempted company incorporated under the laws of the Cayman Islands with limited liability on
November 3, 2020 for the purpose of completing an initial public offering of Diversey Common Stock and related
transactions and in order to carry on the business of our indirect wholly-owned operating subsidiaries.

**Reportable Segments**

We report our results of operations in two segments: Institutional and Food & Beverage.

    - **_Institutional - Our Institutional solutions are designed to enhance cleanliness, safety, environmental_**
sustainability, and efficiency for our customers. We offer a broad range of products, services,
solutions, equipment and machines, including infection prevention and personal care, products, floor
and building care chemicals, kitchen and mechanical warewash chemicals and machines, dosing and
dispensing equipment, and floor care machines. We also offer a range of engineering, consulting and
training services related to productivity management, water and energy management, and risk
management, supported by data provided through our digital solutions. We deliver these solutions to
customers in the healthcare, education, food service, retail and grocery, hospitality, and building
service contractors industries.

    - **_Food & Beverage - Our Food & Beverage products are designed to maximize the hygiene, safety, and_**
efficiency of our customers’ production and cleaning processes while minimizing their impact on the
natural resources they consume. We offer a broad range of products, solutions, equipment and
machines including chemical products, engineering and equipment solutions, knowledge-based
services, training through our Diversey Hygiene Academy, and water treatment. We deliver these
solutions to enhance food safety, operational excellence, and sustainability for customers in the
brewing, beverage, dairy, processed foods, pharmaceutical, and agriculture industries.

We evaluate the performance of each reportable segment based on the results of each segment. In addition,
corporate reflects indirect costs that support all segments, but are not allocated or monitored by segment
management, and include executive and administrative functions, finance and accounting, procurement, information
technology and human resources. For additional information regarding key factors and measures used to evaluate
our business, see “—Non-GAAP Financial Measures” and “—Net Sales by Segment.”

**Recent Trends and Events**

**_Russia-Ukraine War_**

The geopolitical situation in Eastern Europe intensified on February 24, 2022 with Russia’s invasion of
Ukraine. The war between the two countries continues to evolve as military activity proceeds and additional
economic sanctions are imposed on Russia by numerous countries throughout the world. In addition to the human
toll and impact of the war locally in Russia, Ukraine, and neighboring countries that conduct business with their
counterparties, the war is increasingly affecting economic and global financial markets and exacerbating ongoing
economic challenges, including issues such as rising inflation and global supply-chain disruption.

The Russia-Ukraine war has exacerbated the current inflationary environment both in Russia, as a result of
economic sanctions that devalue its currency, and in other countries as their businesses and currencies react to the
war’s implications worldwide. It is possible that foreign currency restrictions or the development of multiple
exchange rates could arise in certain countries. In addition, if there are inflationary pressures in Russia and the
neighboring countries, we may be required to assess whether the economies of those countries have become highly
inflationary, in which the U.S. dollar would replace the Russian ruble as the functional currency for our subsidiaries
in Russia.

Our businesses in Russia and Ukraine generate an immaterial percentage of our overall Net sales.

**_Supply Chain Disruptions_**

The COVID-19 pandemic had a meaningful impact on our business, especially within our Institutional
segment. As economies around the world reopened, increases in demand created significant disruptions to the global
supply chain during 2022, which affected our ability to receive goods on a timely basis and at anticipated costs.
These supply chain disruptions have been caused and compounded by many factors, including changes in supply
and demand, industry capacity constraints, raw material shortages and labor shortages. Global logistics network
challenges have resulted in delays, shortages of certain materials, and increased transportation costs. We have
materially mitigated to date the impact of these disruptions through the work of our procurement and supply chain
teams, but there continues to be significant uncertainties regarding the future impact of supply chain disruptions,
which we cannot predict. Additionally, we continue the process of consolidating certain facilities within North
America, which includes opening a new manufacturing and warehousing facility, which have presented short-term
operational challenges and supply chain disruptions.

We are a diversified business in regards to both industry segments and global geographic regions. These
different aspects of our business are each impacted differently by supply chain disruptions and broader economic
conditions. Therefore, the recovery cycle and related timing is also different for each segment and region.

**_Capital Investments_**

On February 21, 2023, we acquired NSS Enterprise, Inc., a manufacturer of floor cleaning machines based
in the United States. This acquisition will enable the onshore assembly of floor cleaning machines in North America,
which we expect will significantly improve our scale, presence and support in the marketplace.

**_Impact of Inflation_**

Inflation affects our manufacturing, distribution and operating costs. We experienced unprecedented
inflation in 2022, which impacted the cost of our raw materials, packaging and transportation. Cost estimates for our
restructuring project in North America and Europe have also been impacted by the inflationary macro environment
with constraints around materials, freight and labor. Extraordinary short-term measures were taken to minimize
disruption to customers. These measures include lengthening warehouse leases, temporarily setting up additional
warehouses, paying higher freight costs during warehouse transitions and paying carriers to guarantee delivery.
Inflation declined slightly in the first quarter of 2023, but continues to be well above historical levels. We are
committed to maintaining our margins, and have taken actions to mitigate inflation through price increases, cost
control, raw material substitutions, and more efficient logistics practices. However, our success is dependent on
competitive pressures and market conditions, and we cannot guarantee the negative impacts of inflation can be fully
recovered. In periods of significant inflation, we may experience a lag between our ability to recover both the cost
and margin in the short term.

149


-----

**_Financial Market Volatility_**

In the first quarter of 2023, the U.S. and global banking sector experienced increased volatility as a result of
several distressed or closed banks and financial institutions. While we have not realized any losses as a result of the
increased financial market volatility, we continue to monitor the situation and will take appropriate measures, as
necessary, to minimize potential risk exposure to our customers’ and our cash and investment balances.

**Other Factors Affecting Our Operating Results**

Our operating results have been, and will likely continue to be, affected by numerous factors, including the
increasing worldwide demand for our products and services, increasing regulatory compliance costs,
macroeconomic and political conditions, the introduction of new and upgraded products, recent acquisitions and
foreign currency exchange rates. Each of these factors is briefly discussed below.

**_Increasing Demand for Our Products and Services_**

Governmental regulations for food safety and disease control, and consumer focus on hygiene and
cleanliness have increased significantly across the world in recent years. Climate change, water scarcity and
environmental concerns have combined to create further demand for products, services and solutions designed to
minimize waste and support broader sustainability. In addition, many of our customers require tailored cleaning
solutions that can assist in reducing labor, energy, water-use and the costs related to cleaning, sanitation and hygiene
activities. We help our customers realize efficiencies throughout the operation of their facilities by developing
customized solutions. We believe that our value-added customer service approach and proven commitment to
providing cost-savings and sustainable solutions position us well to address these and other critical demand drivers
in order to drive revenue growth.

**_Increasing Regulatory Compliance Costs_**

Although our industry has always been highly regulated, it is becoming more regulated with the
introduction of, among other things, the Environmental Protection Agency Biocidal Product Regulation and the
Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals. Compliance costs associated with these
new regulations have impacted our cost of doing business, and we expect these regulations and other existing and
new regulations to continue to affect our cost of doing business in the future.

**_Impact of Currency Fluctuations_**

We have significant international operations with 82.2% of our Net sales for the three months ended March
31, 2023, being generated from sales to customers located outside of the United States. Our international operations
are subject to changes in regional and local economic conditions, including local inflationary pressures.

We present the Diversey Consolidated Financial Statements in U.S. dollars. As a result, we must translate
the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses of all of our operations into U.S. dollars at applicable exchange rates.
Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of the U.S. dollar may affect the value of these items with respect
to our non-U.S. dollar businesses in the Diversey Consolidated Financial Statements, even if their value has not
changed in their local currency. A stronger U.S. dollar reduces the relative value of reported results of non-U.S.
dollar operations, and, conversely, a weaker U.S. dollar increases the relative value of the non-U.S. dollar
operations. These translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods
and/or result in significant changes to the carrying value of our assets, liabilities and stockholders’ equity. During
2022, the U.S. dollar significantly strengthened against the Euro and other European currencies, peaking in the third
quarter. The U.S. dollar has since trended weaker, and fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates did not have a
significant impact on our reported results in the first quarter of 2023.

In addition, many of our operations buy materials and incur expenses in a currency other than their
functional currency. As a result, our results of operations are impacted by currency exchange rate fluctuations
because we are generally unable to match revenues received in foreign currencies with expenses incurred in the
same currency. From time to time, as and when we determine it is appropriate and advisable to do so, we may seek
to mitigate the effect of exchange rate fluctuations through the use of derivative financial instruments.

**_Net sales by Segment_**

In “Net sales by Segment” and in certain of the discussions and tables that follow, we exclude the impact of
foreign currency translation when presenting Net sales information, which we define as “constant dollar,” and we
exclude acquisitions in the first year after closing and the impact of foreign currency translation when presenting Net
sales information, which we define as “organic.” Changes in Net sales excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation is a Non-GAAP financial measure. As a global business, it is important that we take into account the
effects of foreign currency translation when we view our results and plan our strategies. Nonetheless, we cannot
control changes in foreign currency exchange rates. Consequently, when we look at our financial results to measure
the core performance of our business, we may exclude the impact of foreign currency translation by translating our
current period results at prior period foreign currency exchange rates. We also may adjust for the impact of foreign
currency translation when making incentive compensation determinations. As a result, we believe that these
presentations are useful internally and useful to investors in evaluating our performance.

**_Cost of sales and gross profit. Cost of sales is primarily comprised of direct materials and supplies_**
consumed in the production of product, as well as labor and direct overhead expense necessary to acquire and
convert the purchased materials and supplies into finished products. Also included are expenses associated with
service organization, quality oversight, warranty costs and share-based compensation.

Our gross profit was $219.6 million during the three months ended March 31, 2023 and $236.1 million
during the three months ended March 31, 2022, and our gross margin was 31.6% during the three months ended
March 31, 2023 and 35.8% during the three months ended March 31, 2022. Gross profit during the three months
ended March 31, 2023 was unfavorably impacted by $18.1 million of non-recurring costs related to consolidating
certain manufacturing and warehousing facilities within Europe and North America, $17.2 million of foreign
currency translation, and a $1.8 million increase in share-based compensation. Gross profit was positively impacted
by higher sales volumes and price increases as described above, which were offset by additional freight costs,
increased inflation, and higher labor and manufacturing costs.

**_Selling, general and administrative expenses. Selling, general and administrative expenses are comprised_**
primarily of marketing, research and development and administrative costs. Administrative costs, among other
things, include share-based compensation, professional consulting expenditures, administrative salaries and wages,
certain software and hardware costs and facilities costs.

Selling, general and administrative expenses were $219.1 million during the three months ended March 31,
2023 compared to $213.7 million during the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase of $5.4 million was
primarily due to increases in employee compensation and benefit costs due to inflationary labor increases. These
increases were partially offset by $11.5 million of favorable foreign currency translation and a $5.9 million decrease
in share-based compensation.

**_Transaction and integration costs. Transaction and integration costs were $8.0 million during the three_**
months ended March 31, 2023 and $4.5 million during the three months ended March 31, 2022. These costs consist
primarily of professional and consulting services which are non-operational in nature, costs related to strategic
initiatives, acquisition-related costs, costs incurred in preparing to become a publicly traded company, and costs
related to the Acquisition.

translation had a negative effect of $191.0 million. On a constant dollar basis, Net sales increased $224.1 million, or
11.7%, with our acquisitions contributing $49.3 million of growth. Organic sales increased by 9.1% in 2022 as
compared to 2021, primarily due to price increases to mitigate the effect of inflation, and volume growth (excluding
Infection Prevention products) through a combination of new customer wins, innovation, and continued expansion
with our existing customers. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in sales of Infection Prevention
products, which have returned to a more normalized level, after demand increased significantly in 2020 and in the
first quarter of 2021.

**Food & Beverage. Net sales increased $113.9 million, or 16.3%, in 2022 compared with 2021. Foreign**
currency translation had a negative effect of $81.3 million. On a constant dollar basis, Net sales increased $195.2
million, or 27.9%, with our acquisitions contributing $42.6 million of growth. Organic sales increased by 21.8%
primarily due to price increases, volume growth through new customer wins, and success with the rollout of water
treatment solutions.

Cost of sales and gross profit. Cost of sales is primarily comprised of direct materials and supplies
consumed in the production of product, as well as labor and direct overhead expense necessary to acquire and
convert the purchased materials and supplies into finished products. Also included are expenses associated with
service organization, quality oversight, warranty costs and share-based compensation.

**For the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2021**

Our gross profit was $875.8 million in 2022 and $1,017.3 million in 2021, and our gross margin was 31.7%
in 2022 and 38.8% in 2021. Gross profit for 2022 was unfavorably impacted by $99.4 million of foreign currency
translation, $84.8 million of non-recurring costs related to consolidating certain manufacturing and warehousing
facilities within Europe and North America, and an $18.3 million charge for excess inventory related to COVID-19,
which were offset by a $7.8 million decrease in share-based compensation. Excluding the impact of these items,
gross profit decreased by $53.2 million during 2022, and was positively impacted by price increases and higher sales
volumes as described above, which were offset by increased inflation, additional freight costs, and higher labor and
manufacturing costs.

**_Selling, general and administrative expenses_**

Selling, general and administrative expenses are comprised primarily of marketing, research and
development and administrative costs. Administrative costs, among other things, include share-based compensation,
professional consulting expenditures, administrative salaries and wages, certain software and hardware costs and
facilities costs.

**For the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2021**

Selling, general and administrative expenses were $797.6 million in 2022 compared to $826.8 million in
2021. The decrease of $29.2 million during 2022 was due in part in part to a $51.2 million decrease in share-based
compensation and $65.3 million of favorable foreign currency translation. These decreases were partially offset by
increases in employee compensation and benefit costs due to inflationary labor increases.

**_Transaction and integration costs_**

Transaction and integration costs were $51.3 million, $45.8 million, and $37.0 million during 2022, 2021
and 2020, respectively. These costs consist primarily of professional and consulting services which are non

**_Management fee_**

Pursuant to a management agreement with Bain Capital, we were obligated to pay Bain Capital an annual
management fee of $7.5 million plus reasonable out-of-pocket expenses incurred in connection with management

$19.4 million and $7.5 million in management fees during 2021 and 2020, respectively.

**_Amortization of intangible assets acquired_**

intangible assets, and assumed liabilities were recorded as of the acquisition date at their respective fair values.

and 2020, respectively.

**_Restructuring and exit costs_**

We recorded restructuring and exit costs of $48.7 million, $38.4 million, and $32.1 million during 2022,
2021 and 2020, respectively. In 2021, we began a strategic initiative to consolidate certain manufacturing and
warehousing facilities within Europe and North America, which also includes opening a new manufacturing and
warehousing facility in North America. We anticipate that these actions will both expand our production capacity
and allow us to better manage our inventory, supply chain and workforce. We expect to incur approximately $138.0
million of total costs related to this project, and charged $120.0 million over the life of the project and $111.9
million during the year ended December 31, 2022. Costs incurred in 2022 of $27.1 million are reflected in
restructuring and exit costs and $84.8 million of non-recurring other costs related to facilities consolidations are
reflected in Cost of sales. Our remaining costs for this project are approximately $18.5 million at December 31,
2022. Cost estimates for these projects have been impacted by an inflationary macro environment with constraints
around materials, freight and labor. Extraordinary short-term measures were taken to minimize disruption to
customers. These measures include lengthening warehouse leases, temporarily establishing additional warehouses,
paying higher freight costs during warehouse transitions and paying carriers to guarantee delivery. In the fourth
quarter of 2022, we also incurred restructuring costs related to a reduction in headcount to realign our personnel
resources with our business needs, which was aimed at maintaining a competitive cost structure and workforce
optimization. See Note 18 — Restructuring and Exit Activities in the Notes to the Diversey Consolidated Financial
Statements.
